The boats Flying Dutchman and Europe class were weighed and checked. The remaining sails, rigging and boats were just "stamped". No major measurement issues were found. [[File:Niki Nocke mearuring at the 2012 Vintage Yachting Games.jpg|thumb|Niki Nocke mearuring at the 2008 Vintage Yachting Games]] ===Opening ceremony === The opening ceremony consisted of the following elements: * '''[[Fleet review]]:''' During the part the [[mayor]] of Medemblik acted as fleet admiral. In that role he judged the execution of the manoeuvers of the fleets of Vintage Yachting classes. The 8 Metre Varg was use as the admirals flagship * '''[[Parade]]:''' The sailors walked their flags from the Regatta centre to the medieval castle Radboud. * '''Official opening:''' After the opening speeches and a short video clip of each of the Vintage Yachting Classes in their Olympic days, the mayor declared the Vintage Yachting Games 2008 opened * '''[[Social event]]:''' Finally the sailors and organizers enjoyed the dinner in the castle {{Gallery | title = Opening of the 2008 Vintage Yachting Games | width = 90 | height = 60 | lines = 0 |File:2008 VYG Fleet Review.JPG| |File:2008 Vintage Yachting Games Opening Ceremony.jpg| }} {{Gallery | title = | width = 90 | height = 135 | lines = 4 |File:Fleet review during the 2008 VintageYachting Games.jpg|8 Metre "Varg" acting as the vessel of the Admiral. |File:Theo van Eijk.jpg|Theo van Eijk opening the Vintage }} ===Closing ceremony=== The closing ceremony started with the Vintage InterPares race in the 12’ Dinghies. This was followed by the prize giving. The prizes were handed out by the representatives of the International Class Organizations. During the closing of the event [[Rudy den Outer]] thanked the city of Medemblik for her cooperation. He also announced that “[[Multilario]]”, will be the host of the 2012 Vintage Yachting Games. After that the Vintage flag was received from the mayor of Medemblik, Theo van Eijk[[:nl:Lijst van burgemeesters van Medemblik|Mayors of Medemblik]] by the Project manager of the 2012 Edition of the Vintage Yachting Games: [[Pietro Adamoli]]. This next edition will be organized at [[Lake Como]]. [[File:VYG Flag Transfer 2008.JPG|thumb|The Vintage Flag was transferred from Theo van Eijk (Mayor of Medemblik) to Pietro Adamoli representing the Multilario organization, the 2012 host.]] ===Media coverage=== The official photographer of the 2008 Vintage Yachting Games was [[Marc van Oers]]. The event was covered by the media in several ways: * National TV 'SBS6' (NED) * National newspaper 'Telegraaf' (NED) * Local newspaper 'Noord-Hollands Dagblad' * The Dutch sailing Magazine 'Zeilen' * Several International internet sites for yachting * Web page International Sailing Federation [http://www.sailing.org/regattainfo.php?rgtaid=9792 ISAF] * Web pages International Class Organizations (Vintage Classes) ** [http://www.europeclass.org Europe] ** [http://www.olympiajolle.de O-Jolle] ** [http://www.sailfd.org Flying Dutchman] ** [http://www.soling.com Soling] ** [http://www.intdragon.org Dragon] * Web pages several national Class organizations (Vintage Olympic Classes) == Sailing == Races in all events were sailed in a fleet racing format of seven scheduled races. The contestants raced around a course in one group, and each boat earned a score equal conform the bonus point system. The five best scores for each boat were summed up for the overall score. On Saturday 27 September the wind conditions did not allowed a valid race. ===Reports per event=== Per class separate pages reporting the facts are available (see the details section per class in the medals table). ===Report Vintage InterPares race=== [[File:2008 Vintage InterPares.JPG|thumb|Victor of the Vintage InterPares Race: Szabolcs Majthenyi, representing The International Flying Dutchman]] By crossing colored ribbon Szabolcs Majthenyi, the responsible person of the victorious Hungarian Flying Dutchman, won the Vintage InterPares race 2008. In this race all winners of the Vintage Yachting Games meet each other in a battle between the classes. This race is held in the 12’ Dinghy, an Olympic class in 1920 and 1928. This class is still very active in 10 countries including The Netherlands, Italy and Japan. For privacy reasons the rest of the finishing order will remain a secret. The International Flying Dutchman class was “THE” Vintage Yachting Class till 2012. ==Medal summary== === Medals === [[File:Trophies of the 2008 Vintage Yachting Games.JPG|thumb|Trophies of the 2008 Vintage Yachting Games]] {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event}} |- |align=center|Europe Female:

The organization decided that those teams would show in the results. * Only moments after his arrival at Medemblik, the O-Jolle of [[Felix Hurter]] was stolen from the parkinglot
of the regatta center. Felix was able to race due to the help of the Dutch O-Jolle class organization and [[Hendrik van Isselmuiden]] who lent out his O-Jolle. ==References== {{reflist}} Information about the Vintage Yachting Classes (former Olympic classes) can be verified by the: * International Olympic Committee: [http://www.olympics.org IOC] * International Sailing Federation: [http://www.sailing.org ISAF] * Newport Harbor Nautical Museum: [http://www.nhnm.org Newport Harbor Nautical Museum] * Nederlands Scheepvaartmuseum Amsterdam : [http://www.scheepvaartmuseum.nl Scheepvaartmuseum] and * {{cite book |title=Vintage Yachting Games,Olympic Classes|publisher=2008 Vintage Organizing Committee|location=Bergambacht|year=2008|ISBN=978-90-78440-23-9}} Information about the organization, conditions, sailors and results can be verified by the: * Vintage Yachting Games Organization: [http://www.vintageyachtinggames.org Vintage Yachting Games] * International Europe Class Union: [http://www.europeclass.org Europe] * Olympiajolle Class Union: [http://www.o-jol.nl O-Jolle] * International Flying Dutchman Class Organization: [http://www.sailifdco.com Flying Dutchman] * International Soling Association: [http://www.soling.com Soling] * International Dragon Association: [http://www.intdragon.org Dragon] {{Vintage Yachting Games}} {{Olympic class sailboats}} [[Category:Vintage Yachting Games|2008]] [[Category:2008 in sailing|Vintage Yachting Games, 2008]] [[Category:2008 Vintage Yachting Games| ]]

title: 1982 Virginia vs. Chaminade men's basketball game
text:
{{Infobox NCAABasketballSingleGame |Name=1982 Virginia vs. Chaminade
basketball game |Year=1982 |Type= |Image= |Date=December 23, 1982 |Arena=[[Honolulu International Center]] |City=[[Honolulu|Honolulu, Hawaii]] |Visitor Name Short=Virginia |Visitor Nickname=Cavaliers |Home Name Short=Chaminade |Home Nickname=Silverswords |Visitor Record=8–0 |Home Record=10–1 |Visitor Coach=[[Terry Holland]] |Home Coach=Merv Lopes |Visitor1=43 |Visitor2=29 |Home1=43 |Home2=34 |Visitor AP=1 |Visitor Coaches= |Home AP=NR |Home Coaches= |MVP= |Odds= |Anthem= |Referee=Pat Tanibe |Attendance=3,383 |US Network=None |US Announcers= |Ratings= |Intl Network= |Intl Announcers= }} The '''1982 Virginia vs. Chaminade men's basketball game''' was a [[college basketball]] game between the [[Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball|Virginia Cavaliers]] of the [[University of Virginia]] and the [[Chaminade Silverswords]] of [[Chaminade University of Honolulu]]. The contest was held on December 23, 1982, at the [[Honolulu International Center]] in Honolulu, Hawaii. The Silverswords, then a [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA) member, defeated the Cavaliers, who were the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]'s (NCAA) top-ranked team, 77–72. Chaminade's victory over a Virginia team that included three-time national player of the year [[Ralph Sampson]] has been called college basketball's "biggest upset" by multiple publications.{{cite journal|last=Fine|first=Happy|title=Very small but very deadly|journal=Sports Illustrated|date=January 10, 1983|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1983/01/10/627621/very-small-but-very-deadly|accessdate=July 10, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Chaminade's Win Was Unbelievable; Victory over Sampson, Virginia is game's No. 1 upset|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 24, 2002|page=D1}} ==Background== The Cavaliers entered the Chaminade game with an 8–0 win–loss record in the 1982–83 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The team featured center [[Ralph Sampson]], who had twice been voted national college basketball player of the year; he received similar honors after the 1982–83 season concluded. Earlier in the season, Virginia had won a game on the road against the [[1982–83 Duke Blue Devils men's basketball team|Duke Blue Devils]] by a 13-point margin.{{cite news|last=Song|first=Jaymes|title=Chaminade shocked college basketball 25 years ago|work=USA Today|agency=Associated Press|date=December 20, 2007|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/2007-12-20-136823687_x.htm|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} They had also defeated the [[1982–83 Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball team|Georgetown Hoyas]] in [[Capital Centre|Landover, Maryland]], in what was nicknamed the "Game of the Decade".{{cite journal|last=Wolff|first=Alexander|title=The Greatest Upset Never Seen|journal=Sports Illustrated|date=December 26, 2007|url=https://www.si.com/college-basketball/2007/12/24/greatest-upset1231|accessdate=July 10, 2016}} Afterwards, Virginia participated in a tournament in Tokyo and played against the [[1982–83 Houston Cougars men's basketball team|Houston Cougars]] and [[Utah Utes men's basketball|Utah Utes]], winning both games despite the absence of Sampson, who had been suffering from an intestinal virus. The Cavaliers had hoped to schedule a game against the [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors basketball|Hawaii Rainbows]], but were unsuccessful. They instead decided to play against the Silverswords.{{cite news|last=Tsai|first=Stephen|title=Sampson legitimized Chaminade's upset in 1982|work=The Honolulu Advertiser|date=November 23, 2002|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2002/Nov/23/sp/sp16a.html|accessdate=December 18, 2013}} At the time of the contest, Virginia was the number one ranked team in men's college basketball. Chaminade's basketball program was in its eighth season, and was coming off a record of 28–3 in the 1981–82 season. In the past three seasons, the Silverswords had played the Cavaliers twice, losing both times by double digits.{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Dave|title=Sports of the Times: Virginia Found Gloom in Hawaii|work=The New York Times|date=December 30, 1982|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/30/sports/sports-of-the-times-virginia-found-gloom-in-hawaii.html|accessdate=January 22, 2017}} Eight days before the Virginia game, Chaminade posted its first-ever victory against Hawaii, by a 56–47 margin. On December 21, the Silverswords lost to Wayland Baptist, Chaminade's only defeat in 11 games. The Silverswords were unranked entering the game against Virginia.{{cite book|last=Leung|first=Brian|title=100 Things Virginia Fans Should Know & Do Before They Die|publisher=Triumph Books|year=2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qJfgDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT179|chapter=45. Rick Carlisle|isbn=9781633196742}} (Unpaginated version consulted online via Google Books) ==Game summary== The game was held at Honolulu's [[Neal S. Blaisdell Center|International Center]] with 3,383 people in attendance, less than half of the arena's capacity. According to sportswriter [[Alexander Wolff]], who viewed footage of the game, Chaminade did not attempt to hold possession of the ball for long periods on offense, and often sought to advance quickly up the court after Virginia baskets. [[Michael Wilbon]], a writer for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' who was in attendance, reported that Chaminade's offense mostly consisted of [[Jump shot (basketball)|jump shots]] away from Virginia's basket.{{cite news|last=Wilbon|first=Michael|title=Chaminade 'Amazing' in Va. Upset|work=The Washington Post|date=December 24, 1982|page=D1}} Defensively, the Silverswords focused on guarding their own basket, in an effort to stop Sampson. They attempted to surround Sampson with defenders when he received the basketball. Chaminade [[Center (basketball)|center]] Tony Randolph opened the scoring with a [[slam dunk]] after a short-distance miss by guard Mark Wells. The Silverswords scored six of the game's first eight points, and continued to hold the advantage as the first half progressed. At one point they led 19–12, before a Cavaliers scoring run that gave Virginia a 22–21 lead. Despite the run, the Cavaliers had difficulty shooting field goals. Virginia forward Tim Mullen later said, "I remember us getting like 10 rebounds per possession and missing layups. The ball would not go in." At the end of the first half, the Cavaliers and the Silverswords were tied, 43–43. Virginia gained the lead early in the second half, and a [[Ricky Stokes]] score gave the Cavaliers a seven-point lead with 11:14 remaining. Chaminade responded with a 7–0 scoring run to force a 56–56 tie, before Sampson made a turnaround jump shot to give Virginia the lead back. Immediately after his basket, Sliverswords players Tim Dunham and Mark Rodrigues combined on an [[Alley-oop (basketball)|alley-oop]] play; Rodrigues passed the basketball to Dunham, who dunked over Sampson. Chaminade forward Richard Haenisch said of the basket, "After that play, I think we all got the feeling we could actually win." With less than six minutes left in the second half, the teams were tied at 62–62. Dunham made a 22-foot jumper to give the Silverswords the lead. The Cavaliers forced another tie at 68–68, only for Wells to make a layup with under two minutes on the game clock. Chaminade held a 74–72 lead with 35 seconds remaining, but Virginia gained possession of the basketball after the Silverswords missed a [[free throw]] attempt, which gave the Cavaliers an opportunity to tie the game. However, Virginia was unable to score during the possession; following three missed field goal attempts, Cavaliers player [[Othell Wilson]] committed a [[Carrying (basketball)|carrying]] violation with 10 seconds on the clock. After being fouled by the Cavaliers, Dunham was successful on two free throw attempts, stretching the Silverswords' lead to four points. Wells completed the scoring with another free throw, which made the final score 77–72 in Chaminade's favor. Chaminade was led by Randolph; in 27 minutes on the court, he recorded 19 points with nine made field goals in 12 attempts, along with 5 rebounds. For the game, the Silverswords were successful on 28 of their 57 field goal attempts. Virginia made one more basket, but required 14 more shots than Chaminade to do so. For the Cavaliers, Sampson played 38 minutes, scoring 12 points and pulling down 17 rebounds. He had six of Virginia's 25 turnovers in the contest. ==Aftermath== The result of the game initially was not widely reported in the U.S. media, as it concluded after 3:00 in the morning on the East Coast. Only one sportswriter not based in Hawaii attended the game, Wilbon. He was already in Honolulu on assignment from ''The Washington Post'' as he was sent to cover [[Maryland Terrapins football|the University of Maryland]]'s performance in the [[1982 Aloha Bowl|Aloha Bowl]], and decided to take in the basketball game as well.{{cite news|last=Bolch|first=Ben|title=Improbable basketball victory by small college in Hawaii still resonates|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 19, 2011|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/nov/19/sports/la-sp-1120-college-basketball-upsets-20111120|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} In addition, the contest was not televised.{{cite web|last=Bilas|first=Jay|title=Chaminade's shining moment a win-win upset|publisher=ESPN|date=December 6, 2002|url=http://a.espncdn.com/ncb/columns/bilas_jay/1466328.html|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} However, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' and the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' later identified the game as the greatest upset in the history of college basketball. Author [[Chuck Klosterman]] went further, calling the Silverswords' win "the biggest upset in collegiate sports history".{{cite book|last=Klosterman|first=Chuck|title=Eating the Dinosaur|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2009|page=86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lZurDFJtAWwC&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86|isbn=9781439168486}} Chaminade gained increased prominence after the game, which caused the school to cancel a plan to change its name to the University of Honolulu. The Silverswords finished the 1982–83 season with a record of 33–2.{{cite news|last=Markon|first=John|title=1982's Upset For The Ages: Chaminade 77, No. 1 Cavs 72|work=Daily Press. Richmond Times-Dispatch|date=December 26, 1992|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/1992-12-26/sports/9212260194_1_chaminade-university-virginia-hawaii|accessdate=December 17, 2013}} The Cavaliers ended the season at 29–5, winning 11 of 12 games after playing Chaminade. However, the team fell short of the Final Four in the [[1983 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]]. The Cavaliers lost to eventual national champion [[1982–83 NC State Wolfpack men's basketball team|North Carolina State]], who had already defeated Virginia in the championship game of the [[ACC Basketball Tournament]].{{cite news|last=Simon|first=Mark|title=Island kings on top of world|work=USA Today|date=November 21, 2002|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/acc/2002-11-21-focus-chaminade-uva_x.htm|accessdate=December 18, 2013}} The Silverswords won further games against Division I teams in future seasons. Chaminade followed up the win over the Cavaliers by beating [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|Louisville]] in both 1983 and 1984, by scores of 83–72 and 67–65, showing that the Virginia game was not a one-game fluke for Chaminade.{{cite news|last=Distel|first=Dave|title=It Took Ralph Sampson to Put Chaminade on Basketball Map : Honolulu School Has Made a Habit of Scoring Upsets|work=Los Angeles Times|date=January 17, 1985|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-01-17/sports/sp-7822_1_louisville|accessdate=February 12, 2015}} The second Louisville win was against a Cardinals team ranked 12th in a national poll.{{cite news|title=Chaminade strikes again: Louisville falls|work=The Free Lance-Star|agency=Associated Press|date=December 24, 1984|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19841224&id=BeJNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O4sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3679,4191306|accessdate=December 18, 2013}} Chaminade's victory led to the creation of the [[Maui Invitational Tournament]], an annual event in which the Silverswords compete with seven major college teams. As of 2017, Chaminade has won eight games in the Maui Invitational since its creation in 1984; its most recent win was in 2017 versus the [[2017–18 California Golden Bears men's basketball team|California Golden Bears]].{{cite news|last=Marshall|first=John|title=Chaminade adds Cal to list of Maui upsets with 96–72 victory|work=The Washington Post|agency=Associated Press|date=November 22, 2017|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/colleges/chaminade-adds-cal-to-list-of-maui-upsets-with-96-72-victory/2017/11/22/dde90812-cfce-11e7-a87b-47f14b73162a_story.html|accessdate=December 5, 2017}} The loss knocked Virginia out of the #1 spot in the AP poll, and it would not regain that position again until 35 years later, February 12, 2018.http://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/rankings/_/year/2018/week/15/seasontype/2 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball navbox}} [[Category:1982 in Hawaii]] [[Category:1982–83 Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball season]] [[Category:Chaminade–Honolulu Silverswords men's basketball]] [[Category:College basketball games in the United States]] [[Category:Virginia Cavaliers men's basketball]]

title: 1995 Stanley Cup Finals
text:
{{Infobox Stanley Cup Final |year=1995 |image=1995 NHL Logo.gif |team1='''[[New Jersey Devils]]''' |team1_short=New Jersey |team1_1='''2''' |team1_2='''4''' |team1_3='''5''' |team1_4='''5''' |team1_tot='''4''' |team2=[[Detroit Red Wings]] |team2_short=Detroit |team2_1=1 |team2_2=2 |team2_3=2 |team2_4=2 |team2_tot=0 |mvp=[[Claude Lemieux]] (Devils) |location2=[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] ([[Joe Louis Arena]]) (1,2) |location1=[[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] ([[Brendan Byrne Arena]]) (3,4) |dates=June 17 – 24 |team1_coach=[[Jacques Lemaire]] |team2_coach=[[Scotty Bowman]] |team1_captain=[[Scott Stevens]] |team2_captain=[[Steve Yzerman]] |referees=[[Bill McCreary (referee)|Bill McCreary]] (1,4)
[[Terry Gregson]] (2)
[[Kerry Fraser]] (3) |series_winner=[[Neal Broten]] (7:56, second, G4) |networks= [[Hockey Night in Canada|CBC]] (Canada-English), [[NHL on Fox|Fox]] (United States-games 1, 4), [[ESPN National Hockey Night|ESPN]] (United States-games 2, 3) |net_announcers= [[Bob Cole (sportscaster)|Bob Cole]] and [[Harry Neale]] (CBC), [[Mike Emrick]] and [[John Davidson (ice hockey)|John Davidson]] (Fox), [[Gary Thorne]] and [[Bill Clement]] (ESPN) }} The '''1995 Stanley Cup Finals''' was the [[Stanley Cup Finals|championship series]] of the [[National Hockey League]]'s (NHL) [[1994–95 NHL season|1994–1995 season]], and the culmination of the [[1995 Stanley Cup playoffs]]. It was contested by the [[Eastern Conference (NHL)|Eastern Conference]] champion [[New Jersey Devils]] and the [[Western Conference (NHL)|Western Conference]] champion [[Detroit Red Wings]]. This was the first of nine consecutive finals with American-based franchises exclusively. New Jersey was making the franchise's first appearance in the Finals, while Detroit returned to the Finals for the first time since {{scfy|1966}} (and had not won since {{scfy|1955}}; both of those appearances had been against the [[Montreal Canadiens]]). The Devils swept the series four games to none to win their first [[Stanley Cup]], becoming the sixth team to earn a championship having joined the league in [[1967 NHL expansion|1967]] or later. Despite the fact that the regular season was cut severely short by the owners' [[1994–95 NHL lockout|lockout]], both the season and the finals were saved at the eleventh hour–this would be the latest in June that the Stanley Cup was awarded (matched in {{scfy|2013}}). The Devils won their first Stanley Cup, after 21 seasons and two franchise relocations. It was also the first of three for the Devils in less than a decade. The win was made more impressive by the fact that the Devils won it holding the lowest seed ever to win the Stanley Cup with the fifth seed, which remained the record until {{scfy|2012}}, another Final which not only involved the Devils, but also saw the Stanley Cup won by a team that did not have home ice advantage in any of the four rounds of the playoffs, as the Devils lost to the [[Los Angeles Kings]]. Their regular-season winning percentage was also the lowest since the {{scfy|1967}} [[Toronto Maple Leafs]]. They were the underdogs going in, winning their first two games on the road. This series featured the two teams that have gone to the finals at least four times since the NHL renamed the conferences before the {{NHL Year|1993}} season. Including 1995, the Devils have been to the Finals five times, while the Red Wings have appeared in the Finals six times. It also marked the beginning of a series of wins the Devils, Red Wings, and [[Colorado Avalanche]] would establish in the era from 1995 to {{scfy|2003}}. The three teams would win a combined eight of nine Stanley Cups during that time. The Devils won it here, followed by the Avalanche in {{scfy|1996}}, then the Red Wings in {{scfy|1997}} and {{scfy|1998}}. After the [[Dallas Stars]] won in {{scfy|1999}}, the four-year cycle repeated as the Devils started it again in {{scfy|2000}}, followed by Colorado in {{scfy|2001}}, Detroit in {{scfy|2002}}, and the Devils themselves again in 2003. ==Paths to the Finals== {{further|1995 Stanley Cup playoffs|1994–95 Detroit Red Wings season|1994–95 New Jersey Devils season}} To get to the Final, New Jersey defeated the [[Boston Bruins]] 4–1, the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] 4–1, and their [[Devils–Flyers rivalry|rival]] the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] 4–2. Detroit defeated the [[Dallas Stars]] 4–1, the [[San Jose Sharks]] 4–0, and [[Blackhawks–Red Wings rivalry|then division rival]] [[Chicago Blackhawks]] 4–1. ==Game summaries== ===Game one=== {{IceHockeybox | date = June 17 | time = | team1 = '''New Jersey Devils''' | team2 = Detroit Red Wings | score = 2 – 1 | periods = | reference = http://bigmouthsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/1995-Stanley-Cup-Playoff-boxscores-NJ.pdf | goalie1 = [[Martin Brodeur]] 16 saves / 18 shots | goalie2 = [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]] 19 saves / 23 shots | progression = | goals1 = | goals2 = | official = McCreary | linesman = | linesman2 = | stadium = [[Joe Louis Arena]] | attendance = | penalties1 = | penalties2 = | shots1 = | shots2 = | note = }} The series opened on Saturday, June 17 at the Joe Louis Arena in [[Detroit, Michigan]]. Few gave New Jersey much of a chance against the NHL's best team. Going into the game, Detroit was a perfect 8–0 at home in the playoffs, and had outscored their opponents 30–11 in their eight home games. In the first three rounds alone the Red Wings had scored 18 power-play goals. Detroit fans, first greeting their opponents with a chorus of boos, then chanted after every Devils name was read during introductions, "''Who cares?''" After a scoreless first period, the underdog Devils got on the board first, when [[Stéphane Richer (ice hockey forward)|Stephane Richer]] blasted a slap shot from the top of the right circle that just squeezed through Detroit goaltender [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]]. The power-play goal came at 9:41 of the second period and gave New Jersey a 1–0 lead. The Red Wings responded less than four minutes later and tied the game on a power-play goal by [[Dino Ciccarelli]] at 13:08. The Devils would regain the lead on a goal by [[Claude Lemieux]], a slapper from the slot at 3:17 of the third period. New Jersey would go on to win the game 2–1 and take a one-game-to-none series lead. They played a solid defensive game, frustrating the Red Wings and holding them to just 17 shots. The win was their ninth road win of the playoffs. ===Game two=== {{IceHockeybox | date = June 20 | time = | team1 = '''New Jersey Devils''' | team2 = Detroit Red Wings | score = 4 – 2 | periods = | reference = http://bigmouthsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/1995-Stanley-Cup-Playoff-boxscores-NJ.pdf | goalie1 = [[Martin Brodeur]] 16 saves / 18 shots | goalie2 = [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]] 19 saves / 23 shots | progression = | goals1 = | goals2 = | official = Gregson | linesman = | linesman2 = | stadium = [[Joe Louis Arena]] | attendance = | penalties1 = | penalties2 = | shots1 = | shots2 = | note = }} In game two, Detroit played with a sense of urgency. [[Vyacheslav Kozlov]] scored on the power play at 7:17 of the second period to make the score 1–0 in favor of the Red Wings. Devils forward [[John MacLean (ice hockey)|John MacLean]] would tie the game at 1–1 less than two and a half minutes later with a goal at 9:40. Then, on a Detroit breakaway, New Jersey defenceman and [[Captain (ice hockey)|captain]] [[Scott Stevens]] laid a thundering body check on Kozlov as he made a move to the inside past the New Jersey blue line. Although the Red Wings regained the lead on [[Sergei Fedorov]]'s goal at 1:36 of the third period, the Stevens hit seemed to inspire the Devils. With the midway point of the third period approaching, New Jersey defenceman [[Scott Niedermayer]] picked up the puck in his own zone and skated up the ice. Once over the Detroit blue line, he got a step on Detroit defenceman [[Paul Coffey]] and fired a shot towards the Detroit net. Although the puck missed the net, it bounced off the end boards and came right back to Niedermayer, who shot it past Mike Vernon to tie the game at 2–2. The game remained tied until late in the third period. Devils defenceman [[Shawn Chambers]] fired a shot from the point and the rebound came right to [[Jim Dowd (ice hockey)|Jim Dowd]] who backhanded the puck into the net to give the Devils a 3–2 lead. Stéphane Richer would add an empty-net goal as New Jersey won, 4–2. ===Game three=== {{IceHockeybox | date = June 22 | time = | team1 = Detroit Red Wings | team2 = '''New Jersey Devils''' | score = 2 – 5 | periods = | reference = http://bigmouthsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/1995-Stanley-Cup-Playoff-boxscores-NJ.pdf | goalie1 = [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]]
[[Chris Osgood]] 26 saves / 31 shots | goalie2 = [[Martin Brodeur]] 22 saves / 24 shots | progression = | goals1 = | goals2 = | official = Fraser | linesman = | linesman2 = | stadium = [[Brendan Byrne Arena]] | attendance = | penalties1 = | penalties2 = | shots1 = | shots2 = | note = }} Game three, the very first NHL game ever played after the official [[summer solstice]], shifted the series back to the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, New Jersey. During game one, the Detroit crowd taunted the Devils by collectively jeering "Who cares?" after each player was introduced. The Devils fans countered by raining boos down on the visiting Red Wings and delivering chants of "Red Wings suck." The Devils did their talking on the ice, dominating the Red Wings, scoring five consecutive goals. [[Bruce Driver]], Claude Lemieux, [[Neal Broten]], [[Randy McKay]], and [[Bobby Holik]] all scored to give the Devils a 5–0 lead with 11:46 remaining in the game. Detroit scored twice on power-play goals by Sergei Fedorov and [[Steve Yzerman]] at 16:57 and 18:27 of the third period, but it was insufficient to keep New Jersey from winning a 5–2 game. They now had a commanding three-games-to-none lead in the series. ===Game four=== {{IceHockeybox | date = June 24 | time = | team1 = Detroit Red Wings | team2 = '''New Jersey Devils''' | score = 2 – 5 | periods = | reference = http://bigmouthsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/1995-Stanley-Cup-Playoff-boxscores-NJ.pdf | goalie1 = [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]] 21 saves / 26 shots | goalie2 = [[Martin Brodeur]] 14 saves / 16 shots | progression = | goals1 = | goals2 = | official = McCreary | linesman = | linesman2 = | stadium = [[Brendan Byrne Arena]] | attendance = | penalties1 = | penalties2 = | shots1 = | shots2 = | note = }} The Devils jumped out to a 1–0 lead on Neal Broten's goal just 68 seconds into the game. However, the Red Wings were fighting to stay alive and tied the game on Sergei Fedorov's goal just 55 seconds later. Coffey scored a shorthanded goal at 13:01 to give Detroit a 2–1 lead. New Jersey responded less than five minutes later, at 17:45 on a slap-shot goal by Shawn Chambers that beat Mike Vernon glove-side. Then, in the second period, Scott Niedermayer passed to Broten, who chipped the puck over Vernon's glove from just in front of the net. The goal, Broten's second of the game, gave the Devils a 3–2 lead. New Jersey would increase its lead with goals by [[Sergei Brylin]] and Chambers (his second of the game) at 7:46 and 12:32 of the third period. The Devils won the game 5–2 and the series four games to none. It was New Jersey's first [[List of Stanley Cup champions|Stanley Cup Championship]] in team history. Devils [[goaltender]] [[Martin Brodeur]] allowed just seven goals against the Red Wings in the series and Devils forward Claude Lemieux was awarded the [[Conn Smythe Trophy]] as playoff MVP, having led all skaters in playoff goals with 13. He would win the Stanley Cup again the very next season with the Colorado Avalanche. ==Broadcasting== In the United States, this was the first year that Fox broadcast the Stanley Cup Finals. Fox broadcast games one and four with [[Mike Emrick]] and [[John Davidson (ice hockey)|John Davidson]], while ESPN broadcast games two and three with [[Gary Thorne]] and [[Bill Clement]]. Because the Devils swept the Red Wings and game four of the series was on Fox, their television play-by-play announcer, [[Mike Emrick]], called the win, alongside [[John Davidson (ice hockey)|John Davidson]], as they both were the lead broadcast team. That game, the first Stanley Cup-clinching game to air on network television in the United States since game six in {{scfy|1980}}, drew a 4.7 rating and a 10 share.{{cite news|title=FOX'S RATING IN FINALE SOARS|date=June 26, 1995|newspaper=The Buffalo News|page=D3}} In the New York City area, the game drew a 10.6 rating and 21 share and in Detroit, 14.1 and 26. In Canada, [[Bob Cole (announcer)|Bob Cole]] and [[Harry Neale]] were in the broadcast booth as usual. On the radio side, the series was broadcast continentally on [[NHL Radio]] with [[Kenny Albert]] and [[Gary Green (ice hockey)|Gary Green]] announcing. Devils team broadcasters Mike Miller and [[Sherry Ross]] called the series on local radio on [[WABC (AM)|WABC–AM]] 770 in New York City and Red Wings team broadcasters [[Bruce Martyn]] and [[Paul Woods]] called the series on local radio on [[WJR]]–AM 760 in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. ==New Jersey Devils – 1995 Stanley Cup Champions== {{Stanley Cup champion |defence=*4 [[Scott Stevens]] (Captain) *3 [[Ken Daneyko]] *6 [[Tommy Albelin]] *7 [[Chris McAlpine]] *23 [[Bruce Driver]] (A) *27 [[Scott Niedermayer]] *28 [[Kevin Dean (ice hockey)|Kevin Dean]] *29 [[Shawn Chambers]] |goaltenders=*30 [[Martin Brodeur]] *31 [[Chris Terreri]] |centers=*9 [[Neal Broten]] *11 [[Jim Dowd (ice hockey)|Jim Dowd]] *14 [[Brian Rolston]] *18 [[Sergei Brylin]] *21 [[Randy McKay]] (also played wing) |wingers=*8 [[Mike Peluso (ice hockey b. 1965)|Mike Peluso]] *12 [[Bill Guerin]] *15 [[John MacLean (ice hockey)|John MacLean]] (A) *16 [[Bobby Holik]] *17 [[Tom Chorske]] *19 [[Bobby Carpenter (ice hockey)|Bob Carpenter]] Jr. *20 [[Danton Cole]] *22 [[Claude Lemieux]] *25 [[Valeri Zelepukin]] *44 [[Stéphane Richer (ice hockey forward)|Stephane Richer]] |non-players= *[[John J. McMullen]] (Owner/Chairman/Governor), Peter McMullen (Vice President) *[[Lou Lamoriello]] (President/General Manager), [[Jacques Lemaire]] (Head Coach), [[Jacques Caron]] (Goaltender Coach) *[[Dennis Gendron]] (Asst. Coach), [[Larry Robinson]] (Asst. Coach), [[Robbie Ftorek]] (AHL Coach) *Alex Abasto (Asst. Equipment Manager), Bob Huddleston (Massage Therapist), Dave Nichols (Equipment Manager) *Ted Schuch (Medical Trainer), Mike Vasalani (Strength-Conditioning Coach), David Conte (Director of Scouting), Milt Fisher (Scout) *Claude Carrie (Scout), Dan Labraaten (Scout), [[Marcel Pronovost]] (Scout) }} ==Aftermath== The Devils narrowly missed a playoff berth by two points in the 1995–96 season, losing out to the fourth year [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] on the final day of the season. In retrospect, however, the 1995 Cup run started a mini-dynasty for the Devils, as they also won Stanley Cups in 2000 and 2003, under head coaches [[Larry Robinson]] and [[Pat Burns]] respectively. Martin Brodeur, Sergei Brylin, Ken Daneyko, Scott Niedermayer and Scott Stevens were the only players to play in every Devils' Stanley Cup title run. The Red Wings won the [[Presidents' Trophy]] again the following season, thanks to a record-setting 62-win campaign. However, the Colorado Avalanche, who had moved from [[Quebec City]] as the [[Quebec Nordiques|Nordiques]], defeated them in six games of the [[1996 Stanley Cup playoffs|conference finals]]. This started a lengthy rivalry between the two teams, which culminated in a [[Red Wings–Avalanche brawl|brawl]] between the two teams at [[Joe Louis Arena]] in 1997. That brawl became the catalyst for Detroit's run to two consecutive Stanley Cups in 1997 and 1998, ending a 42-year title drought. The Red Wings later added two more Stanley Cups in 2002 and {{scfy|2008}}, hiking their total to 11. The 1995 Cup Finals started a four-year period where every Cup Final was a sweep, which ended when the [[Dallas Stars]] needed six games to beat the [[Buffalo Sabres]] in {{scfy|1999}}. ==See also== *[[1994–95 NHL season]] *[[1994–95 Detroit Red Wings season]] *[[1994–95 New Jersey Devils season]] *[[1995 Stanley Cup playoffs]] *[[List of Stanley Cup champions]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book|last=Diamond |first=Dan |title=Total Stanley Cup|year=2000|publisher=NHL}} *{{cite book |author=Podnieks, Andrew |author2=Hockey Hall of Fame |year=2004 |title=Lord Stanley's Cup |publisher=Triumph Books |isbn=978-1-55168-261-7}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[1994 Stanley Cup Finals|New York Rangers
1994]] | after = [[1996 Stanley Cup Finals|Colorado Avalanche
1996]] | title = [[List of Stanley Cup champions|New Jersey Devils
Stanley Cup Champions]] | years = 1995| }} {{s-end}} {{Navboxes| list1= {{Stanley Cup Finals}} {{Detroit Red Wings}} {{New Jersey Devils}} {{NHL on Fox}} {{ESPN National Hockey Night}} {{Hockey Night in Canada}} {{NHL Radio}} }} [[Category:1995 Stanley Cup| ]] [[Category:1994–95 NHL season|Stanley Cup]] [[Category:Detroit Red Wings games]] [[Category:New Jersey Devils games]] [[Category:Stanley Cup Finals]] [[Category:Sports competitions in East Rutherford, New Jersey]] [[Category:20th century in East Rutherford, New Jersey]] [[Category:June 1995 sports events]] [[Category:1995 in sports in New Jersey]] [[Category:1995 in Detroit]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Detroit]] [[Category:1990 in sports in Michigan]]

title: 1999 National League Wild Card tie-breaker game
text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}}
{{Infobox baseball game
|year    = 1999
|game    = National League wild-card tie-breaker game 
|image   = 
|caption = 
|date    = October 4, [[1999 in baseball|1999]]
|venue   = [[Cinergy Field]]
|city    = [[Cincinnati]]
|home    = [[1999 Cincinnati Reds season|Cincinnati Reds]]
|visitor = [[1999 New York Mets season|New York Mets]]
|umpires =  [[Bruce Froemming]], [[Gerry Davis (umpire)|Gerry Davis]], [[Mark Hirschbeck]], [[Ed Rapuano]], [[Rich Rieker]], [[Jeff Nelson (umpire)|Jeff Nelson]]
}}
The '''1999 National League wild-card tie-breaker game''' was a [[one-game playoff|one-game extension]] to [[Major League Baseball]]'s (MLB) [[1999 Major League Baseball season|1999 regular season]], played between the [[New York Mets]] and [[Cincinnati Reds]] to determine the winner of the [[National League]] (NL) [[Major League Baseball wild card|wild card]]. It was played at [[Cinergy Field]] in [[Cincinnati]], on October 4, 1999. The Mets won the game, 5–0, with [[starting pitcher]] [[Al Leiter]] pitching a two-hit [[Shutouts in baseball|shutout]]. As a result, the Mets qualified for the postseason and the Reds did not.

The game was necessary after both teams finished the season with identical [[Winning percentage|win–loss records]] of 96–66. Some described the Mets as collapsing late in the season while the race between the Reds and their division rival [[Houston Astros]] was close enough to create the possibility of a three-way tie. The Reds won a coin flip late in the season which, by rule at the time, awarded them [[home advantage|home field]] for the game. Upon winning, the Mets advanced to [[1999 National League Division Series|NL Division Series]] (NLDS) where they defeated the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], three-games-to-one. They then advanced to the [[1999 National League Championship Series|NL Championship Series]] (NLCS) but were defeated by the [[Atlanta Braves]] in six games, bringing an end to the Mets' season. In [[baseball statistics]], the tie-breaker counted as the 163rd regular-season game by both teams, with all events in the game added to regular-season statistics.

==Background==
{{main article|1999 New York Mets season|1999 Cincinnati Reds season}}
Neither the Mets nor the Reds had made the playoffs the previous season. The Mets finished the 1998 season with an 88–74 record, while the Reds finished below .500, at 77–85.<ref name="98season">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1998.shtml|title=1998 National League Season Summary|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> The Mets had been tied with the [[Chicago Cubs]] and [[San Francisco Giants]] in the 1998 wild-card race as late in the season as September 25, at 88–72.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/games/standings.cgi?date=1998-09-25|title=Standings on Friday, September 25, 1998|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> However, the Mets did not win another game that year and finished their season one game back of the Cubs and Giants who tied at 89–73.<ref name="98season"/> The Cubs and Giants [[1998 National League wild-card tie-breaker game|played a tie-breaker in 1998]], with the Cubs ultimately winning the wild card.<ref name="98season"/> Sports writers said the Mets "blew" their lead and "collapse[d]", later comparing their 1998 season to the Mets' troubles late in the 1999 season.<ref name="lupica">{{cite news |title=New York is capital of baseball once more |last=Lupica |first=Mike |authorlink=Mike Lupica |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] |date=October 5, 1999}}</ref><ref name="bergen"/> [[Rickey Henderson]] and [[Robin Ventura]] joined the Mets prior to the 1999 season and spent the year as their starting [[left fielder]] and [[third baseman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/h/henderi01.shtml|title=Rickey Henderson Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="ventura">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/v/venturo01.shtml|title=Robin Ventura Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="metsstats">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/1999.shtml|title=1999 New York Mets Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> The Reds added [[right fielder]] [[Michael Tucker (baseball)|Michael Tucker]], [[center fielder]] [[Mike Cameron]], and starting pitchers [[Denny Neagle]] and [[Steve Avery]] during the offseason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/t/tuckemi01.shtml|title=Michael Tucker Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/camermi01.shtml|title=Mike Cameron Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100511102702/http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/c/camermi01.shtml| archivedate=May 11, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/a/averyst01.shtml|title=Steve Avery Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100430024645/http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/a/averyst01.shtml| archivedate=April 30, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/n/neaglde01.shtml|title=Denny Neagle Statistics and History|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="redsstats">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CIN/1999.shtml|title=1999 Cincinnati Reds Batting, Pitching, & Fielding Statistics|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref>

The Mets spent 34 days of the 1999 season leading the Eastern Division, but—following a seven-game losing streak from September 21–28 along with an eight-game winning streak by their division rival [[Atlanta Braves]] from September 19–28—the Braves took a commanding 8-game lead in the division that they did not relinquish.<ref name="metsseason">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/1999-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1999 New York Mets Schedule, Box Scores, and Splits|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref><ref name="braveseason">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/ATL/1999-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1999 Atlanta Braves Schedule, Box Scores, and Splits|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Meanwhile, the Reds and Houston Astros were locked in a tight race for the Central division. The Astros led the division for much of the season, but did not lead by more than three games after August 1 except for one day.<ref name="astrosseason">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/HOU/1999-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1999 New York Mets Schedule, Box Scores, and Splits|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=April 12, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100403090942/http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/HOU/1999-schedule-scores.shtml| archivedate=April 3, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="redsseason">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CIN/1999-schedule-scores.shtml|title=1999 Atlanta Braves Schedule, Box Scores, and Splits|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Ultimately, the Astros won the division with a 97–65 record, one game ahead of the 96–66 Reds.<ref name="astrosseason"/><ref name="redsseason"/> The Astros won their 97th game on the final day of the season.<ref name="astrosseason"/> If Houston had not won that game, the Astros, Reds, and Mets would have instead been locked in a three-way tie. [[Bob Costas]] suggested that MLB was lucky to avoid this situation as he believed they had "no reasonable tiebreaker" to deal with it.<ref name="costas">{{cite news |title=Baseball playoffs feature worthy teams, Costas says |first=Rudy |last=Martzke |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=October 5, 1999}}</ref> Had this three-way tie arisen, the Mets would have won the wild card while the Astros and Reds would have played a tie-breaker for the Central division title.<ref>{{cite news |title=Reds better win today, or Cinderella hangs up the cleats |last=Bray |first=Dwayne |newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]] |date=October 3, 1999}}</ref>

The Mets' losing streak late in the season led [[Jayson Stark]] to label them a "sinking ship" in a column on September 30.<ref name="stark">{{cite news |title=Mets wallop Braves |last=Stark |first=Jayson |authorlink=Jayson Stark |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=September 30, 1999}}</ref> However, the Mets broke this streak with a win over dominant pitcher [[Greg Maddux]] and then, following a loss, swept three games from the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]].<ref name="metsseason"/><ref name="stark"/> The sweep included a walk-off win in the final game of the series. The Mets and Pirates were tied 1–1 in the bottom of the ninth inning when Pirates [[Closer (baseball)|closer]] [[Brad Clontz]] threw a [[wild pitch]] which allowed [[Melvin Mora]] to score and win the game, 2–1, tying the Reds' 96–66 record.<ref name="game162">{{cite news |title=Bad pitch strikes up good memories |first=Mike |last=Lupica |authorlink=Mike Lupica |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] |date=October 4, 1999}}</ref> The ''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]'' described this late-season performance as an "agonizing roller coaster ride" for Mets fans.<ref name="wildwin">{{cite news |title=Better Reds than Dead! Wild win gets Mets showdown in Cincy |last1=Egbert |first1=Bill |last2=Bashinsky |first2=Ruth |author3=Hutchinson, Bill |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] |date=October 4, 1999}}</ref> With the Mets and Reds holding the best non-division winning records in the league<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1999.shtml|title=1999 National League Season Summary|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> a tie-breaker was necessary to determine the wild-card winner. Bob Costas said at the time he did not like the wild-card system as he believed it "diminishes the drama and authenticity of a pennant race", although he approved of the playoff teams in 1999.<ref name="costas"/> [[Tim McCarver]] disagreed, arguing that the late-season race between the Mets, Astros, and Reds showed the excitement a wild card can add to the season.<ref name="costas"/> A coin flip conducted earlier that September set the Reds' home park of [[Cinergy Field]] as the location for the tie-breaker game.<ref>{{cite news |title=Reds at home in tie  |newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]] |date=September 30, 1999}}</ref>

==Game summary==
[[File:Rickey Henderson Day Saturday, Aug. 1.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A man in brown pants, a brown vest, and white shirt raises his right hand. He is standing on grass in front of three chairs, one with a bouquet of flowers on it.|Rickey Henderson led off the game with a single, scored the game's first run, and hit a home run in the fifth inning.]]
[[Box score (baseball)|Box score]] for Monday October 4, 1999–7:05 p.m. ([[Eastern Time Zone (Americas)|ET]]) at Cinergy Field in [[Cincinnati]]
{{Linescore|
|Road='''New York Mets'''|RoadAbr=NYM
|R1=2|R2=0|R3=1|R4=0|R5=1|R6=1|R7=0|R8=0|R9=0|RR=5|RH=9|RE=0
|Home=Cincinnati Reds|HomeAbr=CIN
|H1=0|H2=0|H3=0|H4=0|H5=0|H6=0|H7=0|H8=0|H9=0|HR=0|HH=2|HE=0
|RSP=|HSP=
|WP=[[Al Leiter]] (13–12)|LP=[[Steve Parris]] (11–4)|SV=
|RoadHR=[[Edgardo Alfonzo]] (27), [[Rickey Henderson]] (12)|HomeHR=
|}}
The Mets took a quick 2–0 lead with a [[Single (baseball)|single]] by Rickey Henderson to open the game followed immediately by a [[home run]] by [[Edgardo Alfonzo]]. They added to this lead in the third as Alfonzo drew a [[Base on balls|walk]] and then [[John Olerud]] hit a [[Double (baseball)|double]] which advanced Alfonzo to third base. Reds starter [[Steve Parris]] [[Intentional walk|intentionally walked]] [[Mike Piazza]] to [[Bases loaded|load the bases]] and was [[Relief pitcher|relieved]] by Denny Neagle. However, Neagle then walked Robin Ventura to score Alfonzo and extend the lead to 3–0. Neagle remained in the game and yielded a home run to Henderson to lead off the fifth inning for the Mets' fourth run. Neagle then loaded the bases with two outs with walks to Piazza and Ventura followed by a [[Darryl Hamilton]] single, but escaped the inning without further scoring. The Reds [[pinch hitter|pinch hit]] for Neagle in the bottom of the fifth, and [[Danny Graves]] entered for them to pitch the sixth inning. Graves walked [[Rey Ordóñez]] to leadoff the inning, Mets starter Al Leiter [[sacrifice bunt]]ed Ordóñez to second, and following an out he scored on a double by Alfonzo. Graves remained in the game until [[Mark Lewis (baseball)|Mark Lewis]] pinch hit for him in the eighth and [[Dennys Reyes]] relieved him in the ninth. Graves and Reyes held the score steady after the sixth but the Reds' offense did not score against Al Leiter and the Mets won the game, and with it the Wild Card, 5–0.

Al Leiter pitched a [[complete game]] [[shutouts in baseball|shutout]], scattering two hits and four walks across the nine inning start. This was Leiter's first complete game of the season.<ref name="bergen">{{cite news |title=Leiter lifts Mets into playoff party |author=Quinn, T.J. |newspaper=[[The Record (New Jersey)|The Record]] |date=October 4, 1999}}</ref> [[Pokey Reese]] was the only Reds player to reach [[scoring position]] for the entire game, doubling to lead off the bottom of the ninth inning and then advancing to third on a ground out. ''[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Bergen Record]]'' labeled Leiter the Mets' "flag bearer", coming through in games such as this when the team needed him most.<ref name="bergen"/> For example, Leiter had also defeated Greg Maddux in his previous start on September 29 to snap the Mets' seven-game losing streak.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leiter burns Reds, Mets lefty gets hot at perfect time |first=Mike |last=Ganter |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]] |date=October 5, 1999}}</ref> Leiter's [[earned run average]] in the second half of the 1999 season was 1.22 runs lower than in the first.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/split.cgi?n1=leiteal01&year=1999&t=p|title=Al Leiter 1999 Pitching Splits|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Leiter's start earned an 86 [[game score]], which tied for the 14th best total in the National League that season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/mlb/stats/topperformers/_/year/1999/type/pitching/league/nl |title=NL Top Pitching Performances – 1999 |accessdate=May 6, 2010|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref>

==Aftermath==
New York's win clinched the team's fifth postseason berth in franchise history, their first since losing in the [[1988 National League Championship Series]].<ref name="franchise">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/NYM/|title=New York Mets Team History & Encyclopedia|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> The playoff berth made the Mets the second team in MLB history to make the playoffs after being two games back of the leader with three games left to play in the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/baseball/mlb/09/28/playoff.tiebreakers/index.html |title=Playoff tiebreakers through the years |date=September 28, 2005 |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> The Mets defeated the Arizona Diamondbacks in the NLDS in four games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1999_NLDS2.shtml|title=1999 League Division Series|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> This win advanced the Mets to the NLCS where they were defeated by the Atlanta Braves in six games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1999_NLCS.shtml|title=1999 League Championship Series|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> After the defeat, Mets General Manager [[Steve Phillips]] summed up the harrowing weeks the team had been through saying that "we had destiny in our own hands, we lost destiny, we got it back in our own hands...We didn't choke. We didn't fold. We won."<ref>{{cite news|title=Now the Mets Have Whole New Attitude|first=William C.|last=Rhoden|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 20, 1999|page=D3}}</ref>

The Mets performance in the playoffs drew heavy television viewership, with the decisive game of the NLCS scoring the highest [[Nielsen ratings|ratings]] for any League Championship Series broadcast since 1993.<ref name="variety">{{cite news |title=In defeat, Mets win for NBC |last=Bierbaum |first=Tom |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 25, 1999}}</ref> Overall the NLCS averaged 10.9 million viewers, 18% higher than the NLCS had drawn the year before. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' writer Tom Bierbaum argued this was a good sign for the future of baseball because the Mets and [[Boston Red Sox]] had drawn younger viewers during their time in the postseason.<ref name="variety"/> Bierbaum believed that baseball needed fresh teams, not just the often-successful Yankees and Braves, to draw new audiences and grow viewership.<ref name="variety"/>

In [[baseball statistics]] tie-breakers count as regular season games, with all events in them added to regular season statistics. For example, [[Mike Piazza]] grounded into his 27th [[double play]] of the season in the 9th inning, adding to his league-leading total.<ref name="batting">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1999-batting-leaders.shtml|title=1999 National League Batting Leaders|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Similarly, Leiter's performance advanced his position on several 1999 statistical leaderboards including shutouts and walks issued.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1999-pitching-leaders.shtml|title=1999 National League Pitching Leaders|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Reese, Ventura, and Ordóñez won [[Rawlings Gold Glove Award]]s for the season while Piazza and Alfonzo won [[Silver Slugger Awards|Silver Sluggers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/NL/1999-other-leaders.shtml|title=1999 National League Awards, All-Stars, & More Leaders|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Robin Ventura also finished sixth in [[Most Valuable Player Award|Most Valuable Player]] voting, with [[Chipper Jones]] taking the award.<ref name="ventura"/>

The [[New York Yankees]] also made the playoffs in 1999, eventually advancing to the [[1999 World Series]] where they defeated the Atlanta Braves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/1999_WS.shtml|title=1999 World Series|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> Prior to the Mets' elimination [[Mike Lupica]] noted the possibility of a "[[Subway Series]]", a term for a World Series played between two New York-based teams.<ref name="lupica"/> The [[1956 World Series]] between the Yankees and then-[[Brooklyn Dodgers]] was the last such Series. Yankees pitcher [[David Cone]] told Lupica "I want a Subway Series, for selfish reasons. I want to play in one."<ref name="lupica"/> Although the Mets failed to make the Series in 1999 the two met the following year in the [[2000 World Series]] where the Yankees won in five games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/postseason/2000_WS.shtml|title=2000 World Series|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> After their 2000 World Series appearance the Mets did not make the playoffs again until 2006, where they lost in [[2006 National League Championship Series|that NLCS]] in seven games.<ref name="franchise"/> Meanwhile, the Reds did not place in the top two of their division until returning to the playoffs in 2010.<ref name="redsfranchise">{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CIN|title=Cincinnati Reds Team History & Encyclopedia|work=[[Baseball-Reference.com]]|accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref> [[Jack McKeon]] managed the Reds from 1998–2000 and was fired after the 2000 season when the team finished 10 games back of the division leading Cardinals.<ref name="redsfranchise"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Cincinnati Reds fire manager Jack McKeon |last=Kay |first=Joe |newspaper=[[ABC News]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/story?id=100345&page=1 |date=October 2, 2000 |accessdate=May 6, 2010}}</ref>
