title: 1951 NFL Championship Game
text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox NFLChamp |type=nflc |name=1951 |visitor=[[1951 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] |home=[[1951 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] |visitor_qtr1=0 |visitor_qtr2=10 |visitor_qtr3=0 |visitor_qtr4=7 |visitor_qtr5= |visitor_total=17 |home_qtr1=0 |home_qtr2=7 |home_qtr3=7 |home_qtr4=10 |home_qtr5= |home_total=24 |date=December 23, 1951 |stadium=[[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] |city=[[Los Angeles]], [[California]] |attendance = 59,475 |referee=Ronald Gibbs |network=[[NFL on DuMont|DuMont]] |announcers=[[Harry Wismer]] & [[Earl Gillespie]] }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Los Angeles |lat = 34.014 |long = -118.287 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |position = |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 290 }} The '''[[1951 NFL season|1951]] [[National Football League]] Championship Game''' was the 19th NFL [[History of the National Football League championship|championship game]], played December 23 at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].{{cite news |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1951/12/23/page/17/article/browns-defend-pro-crown-against-rams-today |newspaper=Chicago Sunday Tribune |last=Smith |first=Wilfrid |title=Browns defend pro crown against Rams today |date=December 23, 1951 |page=1, part 2}}{{cite news |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1951/12/24/page/15/article/rams-beat-browns-24-17-for-pro-title|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune |last=Smith |first=Wilfrid |title=Rams beat Browns, 24-17, for pro title |date=December 24, 1951 |page=1, part 2}} It was a rematch of the [[1950 NFL Championship Game|previous year's game]] in Cleveland, with the [[1951 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] (8–4) of the National Conference meeting the defending league champion [[1951 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland Browns]] (11–1) of the American Conference. In the league championship game for the third straight year, the Rams were seeking their first NFL title since moving to California in early [[1946 Los Angeles Rams season|1946]] (the [[History of the Cleveland Rams|Cleveland Rams]] won the [[1945 NFL Championship Game|1945 title]], then left a month later). The Browns were favored to win this title game on the road by six points.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dgEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oiMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6351%2C3242740 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |agency=Associated Press |title=Browns are favored to turn back Rams for pro title today |date=December 23, 1951 |page=1, sports}} This was the first NFL championship game to be televised coast-to-coast,MacCambridge, 2005, p. 73. and was [[National Football League television blackout policies|blacked out]] by the league in the southern California area. The [[DuMont Television Network|DuMont Network]] purchased the championship game TV rights from the NFL in May for five years (1951–[[1955 NFL Championship Game|55]]) for $475,000.{{cite news | first = Dan | last = Hall | title = Hallucinations | date = May 22, 1951 | page = 17 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=adM0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=UU4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5906%2C3028635 | newspaper = [[St. Petersburg Times]] | accessdate = October 31, 2011 | quote = Bell said the money received each year under terms of the agreement will be placed in the players' pool.}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TQEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dCMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2618%2C3124769 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |agency= |title=Du Mont buys rights to pro title contest |date=May 22, 1951 |page=6, part 2}}{{cite news | title = Pro Football and DuMont Sign a $475,000 TV Pact | date = May 22, 1951 | publisher = 43 | url = http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive/pdf?res=F10710FF39591A7B93C0AB178ED85F458585F9 | work = [[New York Times]] | accessdate = October 31, 2011 | quote = Bell said the $95,000 received each year under terms of the agreement will be placed in the players' pool.}}{{cite news | title = Fans Rush for Tickets to NFL Playoff Game | date = December 18, 1951 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XMJRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nmoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4260%2C1532124 | newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |agency=Associated Press | page = 18 | accessdate = October 30, 2011}}The Pittsburgh Press and Patton p. 35 incorrectly state it was for $75,000.Rader, 1984, p. 35. The home underdog Rams upset the Browns 24–17 for their first (and only) NFL championship as a California team, before a then-record crowd for the title game of 59,475.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YcJRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nmoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4070%2C108105 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |agency=Associated Press |title=Rams upset Browns, 24-17; win NFL title |date=December 24, 1951 |page=12}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dwEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oiMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4988%2C3778143 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |last=Kuechle |first=Oliver E. |title=Los Angeles wins pro title by beating Cleveland, 24-17 |date=December 24, 1951 |page=4, part 2 }} The "World Championship" banner awarded to the Rams was given as a gift to Tom Bergin after the game in gratitude for hosting the post-game dinner. As of 2016 it still hangs in the Tom Bergin's Irish pub in Los Angeles, the only one in private ownership. This was also the first time that the Browns under Paul Brown did not finish the season with a championship after 4 wins in the AAFC and a championship in their first NFL season in 1950. ==Game summary== The Rams were the first to score, with a 1-yard run by fullback [[Dick Hoerner]] in the second quarter. The Browns answered back with an NFL Championship record 52-yard field goal by [[Lou Groza]]. They later took the lead with a 17-yard touchdown pass from [[Otto Graham]] to [[Dub Jones (American football)|Dub Jones]], and the Browns led at halftime, 10–7. In the third quarter, Ram [[Larry Brink]] landed a hard tackle on Graham, causing him to fumble the ball, which [[Andy Robustelli]] picked up on the Cleveland 24 and returned it to the two-yard-line. On third down from the one, [[Dan Towler|"Deacon" Dan Towler]] ran the ball in for a touchdown to give the Rams a 14–10 lead. Early in the fourth quarter, the Rams increased their lead with a 17-yard field goal by [[Bob Waterfield]]. The Browns answered back with an 8-play, 70-yard drive that ended with a 5-yard touchdown run by [[Ken Carpenter (football player)|Ken Carpenter]] to tie the game at 17–17. Twenty-five seconds later late in the fourth quarter, [[Tom Fears]] beat defenders [[Cliff Lewis (quarterback)|Cliff Lewis]] and [[Tommy James (football player)|Tommy James]] and received a [[Norm Van Brocklin]] pass at midfield and raced to the end zone for a 73-yard touchdown. It secured a Rams 24–17 win and the 1951 NFL title, their sole league championship in 49 years in southern California. The next NFL title for the franchise came 48 years later, when the [[1999 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]] won [[Super Bowl XXXIV]] in January 2000. ===Scoring summary=== ''Sunday, December 23, 1951''
Kickoff: 1:05 p.m. [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] *'''First quarter''' ** ''no scoring'' *'''Second quarter''' **LA   – TD, [[Dick Hoerner]] 1 run ([[Bob Waterfield]] kick), 7–0 LA **CLE – FG, [[Lou Groza]] 52, 7–3 LA **CLE – TD, [[Dub Jones (American football)|Dub Jones]] 17 pass from [[Otto Graham]] (Groza kick), 10–7 CLE *'''Third quarter''' **LA   – TD, [[Dan Towler]] 1 run (Waterfield kick), 14–10 LA *'''Fourth quarter''' **LA   – FG, Waterfield 17, 17–10 LA **CLE – TD, [[Ken Carpenter (football player)|Ken Carpenter]] 5 run (Groza kick), 17–17 tie **LA   – TD, [[Tom Fears]] 73 pass from [[Norm Van Brocklin]] (Waterfield kick), 24–17 LA ==Officials== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} *'''Referee:''' Ronald Gibbs *'''Umpire:''' Samuel Wilson *'''Head Linesman:''' Dan Tehan *'''Field Judge:''' Lloyd Brazil *'''Back Judge:''' Norman Duncan {{col-break|gap=4em}} *Alternate: Emil Heintz *Alternate: Cletus Gardner {{col-end}} The NFL added the fifth [[Official (American football)|official]], the back judge, in {{nfly|1947}}; the line judge arrived in {{nfly|1965}}, and the side judge in {{nfly|1978}}. ==Players' shares== The gross receipts for the game, including $75,000 for radio and television rights, was just under [[United States dollar|$]]326,000, the highest to date, passing the previous record of $283,000 five years earlier in [[1946 NFL Championship Game|1946]]. Each player on the winning Rams team received $2,108, while Browns players made $1,483 each.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dwEqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oiMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4761%2C3779039 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |agency=Associated Press |title=Rams collect $2,108 each |date=December 24, 1951 |page=4, part 2}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== * [http://www.nfl.com/history/chronology/1951-1960#1951 NFL Chronology: 1951]. ''NFL.com''. Retrieved September 17, 2006. * Brown, Paul; with Clary, Jack (1979). ''PB, the Paul Brown Story''. New York: Atheneum. * Hession, Joseph (1987). ''The Rams: Five Decades of Football''. San Francisco: Foghorn Press. * MacCambridge, Michael (2005). ''America's Game''. New York: Anchor Books {{ISBN|978-0-307-48143-6}} * Powers, Ron (1984). ''Supertube: The Rise of Television Sports''. New York: Coward-McCann. {{ISBN|0-698-11253-9}} * Rader, Benjamin G. (1984). ''In its Own Image: How Television Has Transformed Sports''. New York: The Free Press. {{ISBN|0-02-925700-X}} pp. 83–99. * Riffenburgh, Beau, (1997). "Championships & Playoffs." Eds Silverman, Matthew, et al. ''Total Football II: The Official Encyclopedia of the National Football League''. New York: HarperCollins. 178–262. {{ISBN|0-06-270174-6}} * {{cite news | first = Harold | last = Sauerbrie | title = Browns Lose Title to Rams, 24–17 | date = December 23, 1951 | publisher = Cleveland Live, LLC | url = http://www.cleveland.com/brownshistory/plaindealer/index.ssf?/browns/more/history/19511223BROWNS.html | work = [[The Plain Dealer|Cleveland Plain Dealer]] | pages = 18 | accessdate = December 12, 2007}} {{coord|34.014|-118.287|type:event|display=title}} {{1951 NFL season by team}} {{1951 Los Angeles Rams}} {{Los Angeles Rams}} {{Cleveland Browns}} {{NFL pre-sb}} {{NFL on DuMont}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1951 Nfl Championship Game}} [[Category:1951 National Football League season|Championship Game, 1951]] [[Category:National Football League Championship games]] [[Category:Cleveland Browns postseason]] [[Category:Los Angeles Rams postseason]] [[Category:December 1951 sports events]]

title: The Boat Race 2012
text:
{{Infobox University Boat Race | name= 158th Boat Race | image=Boat Race 2012 In Hammersmith 2 (7055117285).jpg | caption= The Oxford ''(left)'' and Cambridge ''(right)'' boats near [[Hammersmith Bridge]] during the race | winner = Cambridge | margin = 4 and 1/4 lengths | winning_time= 17 minutes 23 seconds | date= {{Start date|2012|04|7|df=y}} | umpire = [[John Garrett (rower)|John Garrett]]
(Cambridge) | prevseason= [[The Boat Race 2011|2011]] | nextseason= [[The Boat Race 2013|2013]] | overall =81–76 | reserve_winner = Isis | women_winner = Cambridge }} The '''158th Boat Race''' took place on 7 April 2012. Held annually, [[The Boat Race]] is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] race between crews from the Universities of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] along the [[River Thames]] in London. Despite Cambridge having the heavier crew, Oxford were pre-race favourites having had a successful preparation period, including a victory over [[Leander Club|Leander]]. Cambridge won the toss and chose to start on the Surrey side of the river. Partway through, with the boats level, the race was temporarily halted to avoid injury to protester Trenton Oldfield, who swam in front of the two crews. After the race was restarted, one of the Oxford crew suffered irreparable damage to his [[Blade (rowing)|blade]] following a clash of oars with the Cambridge boat, ending Oxford's chances of victory. The race was eventually won by Cambridge by four-and-a-quarter lengths, in a consolidated time of 17 minutes 23 seconds. Immediately after completing the race, a member of the Oxford crew collapsed, but later recovered. Oldfield was later jailed for six months for causing a public nuisance, and as a result of the disruption, security for subsequent Boat Races was increased. The reserve race was won by Oxford's Isis in a record time, while the [[Women's Boat Race]] was won by Cambridge. ==Background== [[The Boat Race]] is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] competition between the [[University of Oxford]] (sometimes referred to as the "Dark Blues"){{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/apr/06/theobserver | work = [[The Observer]] | title = Dark Blues aim to punch above their weight | date = 6 April 2003 | accessdate = 8 April 2014 }} and the [[University of Cambridge]] (sometimes referred to as the "Light Blues"). The race was first held in 1829, and since 1845 has taken place on the {{convert|4.2|mi|km|adj=on}} [[The Championship Course|Championship Course]] on the [[River Thames]] in southwest London.{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/uk/london/10719622/University-Boat-Race-2014-spectators-guide.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate = 3 June 2014 | date = 25 March 2014 |title = University Boat Race 2014: spectators' guide | first = Oliver |last =Smith}}{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/the-course | title = The Course| accessdate = 24 July 2014 | publisher = The Boat Race Company Ltd}} The rivalry is a major point of honour between the two universities, followed throughout the United Kingdom and broadcast worldwide.{{cite news|title=Former Winnipegger in winning Oxford-Cambridge Boat Race crew|date=6 April 2014|publisher=[[CBC News]]|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/former-winnipegger-in-winning-oxford-cambridge-boat-race-crew-1.2600176|accessdate=7 April 2014}}{{Cite web | url = http://theboatrace.org/men/tv-and-radio| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006123036/http://theboatrace.org/men/tv-and-radio | archivedate= 6 October 2014 | title = TV and radio | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited | accessdate = 7 July 2014}} Oxford went into the 2012 race as reigning champions, having beaten Cambridge by four lengths in the [[The Boat Race 2011|previous year's race]]. However, Cambridge held the overall lead, with 80 victories to Oxford's 76.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2012/apr/07/boat-race-wins-oxford-cambridge | work = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 24 July 2014 | title = Cambridge vs Oxford: all the boat race winners listed | date = 7 April 2012 | first = Ami | last = Sedghi}} Oxford were pre-race favourites, having beaten [[Leander Club|Leander]], [[Molesey Boat Club]] and a German national under-23 crew in the previous weeks.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/news-article/race-report-the-2012-xchanging-boat-race | publisher = The Boat Race Company Ltd | title = Race report – The 2012 Xchanging Boat Race | date = 7 April 2012 | first = Peter | last = McConnell | accessdate=20 May 2014}} The first [[Women's Boat Race]] took place in 1927, but did not become an annual fixture until the 1960s. Until 2014, the contest was conducted as part of the [[Henley Boat Races]], but as of the [[The Boat Races 2015|2015 race]], it is held on the River Thames [[Tideway]], on the same day as the men's main and reserve races.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/women/history | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141006112628/http://theboatrace.org/women/history| archivedate= 6 October 2014| title = A brief history of the Women's Boat Race | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited| accessdate = 5 July 2014}} The reserve race, contested between Oxford's Isis boat and Cambridge's [[Goldie (Cambridge University Boat Club)|Goldie]] boat, has been held since 1965. It usually takes place on the Thames, prior to the main Boat Race.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/results| publisher = The Boat Race Company Ltd | title = Boat Race – Results| accessdate = 29 June 2014}} ==Crews== {| class="wikitable floatright" |- ! rowspan="2" scope="col| Seat ! colspan="3" scope="col| Cambridge ! colspan="3" scope="col| Oxford |- ! Name ! Nationality ! Weight ! Name ! Nationality ! Weight |- | [[Bow (rowing)|Bow]] || Moritz Schramm || German || {{convert|91.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Alex Woods || British || {{convert|77.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 2 || Jack Lindeman || American || {{convert|94.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || William Zeng || American || {{convert|82.4|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 3 || Mike Thorp || British || {{convert|91.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Kevin Baum || American || {{convert|91.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 4 || David Nelson (P) || Australian || {{convert|92.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Hanno Wienhausen || German || {{convert|93.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 5 || Alexander Scharp || American || {{convert|95.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Karl Hudspith (P) || British || {{convert|92.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 6 || Steve Dudek || American || {{convert|109.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Alex Davidson ||British || {{convert|94.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | 7 || Alex Ross || New Zealand || {{convert|102.0|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Dan Harvey || British || {{convert|79.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | [[Stroke (rowing)|Stroke]] || Niles Garratt || American || {{convert|92.2|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || Roel Haen || Dutch || {{convert|96.8|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- | [[Coxswain (rowing)|Cox]] || Ed Bosson|| British || {{convert|55.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} || [[Zoe De Toledo|Zoe de Toledo]] || British || {{convert|49.6|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |- !colspan="7"|(P) – Boat club president
Source:{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rowing/17259600 | title = The Boat Race 2012: Cambridge outweigh rivals Oxford | date = 5 March 2012 | publisher = [[BBC Sport]]| accessdate =18 May 2014}} |} The trial crews competed against one another on 13 December 2011 on The Championship Course. Oxford's boats were titled ''Hell'' and ''High Water'', while Cambridge's two crews rowed in ''Cloak'' and ''Dagger''.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/crews-announced-for-trial-eights-test |date = 12 December 2011 | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited| title = Crews announced for trial eights test | accessdate=18 May 2014}} ''Hell'' and ''Dagger'' won their respective races.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/16/results-from-the-trial-eights | date=13 December 2011 | title = Results from the trial eights | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited | accessdate=18 May 2014}} The official crews were announced at the weigh-in, held on 5 March 2012 at a venue nearby the [[Olympic Stadium (London)|London 2012 Olympic Stadium]].{{Cite web | url = http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/official-158th-boat-race-crews-announced-today | date= 5 March 2012 | title = Official 158th Boat Race crews announced today | publisher =The Boat Race Company Limited|accessdate = 18 May 2014}} For the first time in Cambridge's Boat Race history, their boat featured just one British oarsman, Mike Thorp, who, along with stroke David Nelson and Oxford's number five Karl Hudspith, were the only participants who had featured in the [[The Boat Race 2011|2011 race]]. The remainder of the Cambridge crew comprised three Americans, two Australians, a German, a New Zealander and cox Ed Bosson, another Briton. The Oxford crew consisted of a British cox, four British oarsmen, two Americans, a German and a Dutch rower. The Cambridge oarsmen weighed an average of {{convert|7.9|kg|lb}} more than their Oxford counterparts, with Cambridge's cox Ed Bosson outweighing Oxford's [[Zoe De Toledo|Zoe de Toledo]] by {{convert|6|kg|lb}}. Despite the fact that heavier [[Oxbridge]] crews were traditionally more successful, [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford boat club]] president Hudspith, himself part of the successful 2011 Dark Blue crew which defeated a heavier Cambridge crew,{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/8367315/Boat-Race-2011-Oxford-remain-defiant-despite-champions-Cambridge-leading-the-way-at-official-weigh-in.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate = 12 July 2014 | date = 7 March 2011 | first = Rachel | last = Quarrell | title = Boat Race 2011: Oxford remain defiant despite champions Cambridge leading the way at official weigh-in}} downplayed the disparity, "It's a big difference but it's a very long race and you have to have the power to carry that weight down the course". ==Races== [[File:University Boat Race Thames map.svg|right|thumb|[[The Championship Course]] along which the Boat Race is contested]] ===Women's and reserves=== The [[Women's Boat Race 2012|women's race]], the 66th meeting of [[Cambridge University Women's Boat Club]] and [[Oxford University Women's Boat Club]],{{Cite web | url = http://henleyboatraces.com/results | publisher = [[Henley Boat Races]] | accessdate = 20 May 2014 | title = Results}} was held at the [[Henley Boat Races]] on 25 March.{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9068436/Boat-Race-becomes-the-Boat-Races-as-women-and-mens-university-events-are-combined-for-2015.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | title = Boat Race becomes 'the Boat Races' as women and men's university events are combined for 2015 | first = Rachel | last = Quarrell | date = 8 February 2012 | accessdate = 16 July 2014}} In a close race, Cambridge won by a quarter of a length, in a time of 6 minutes, 38 seconds. Oxford's Osiris won the women's reserve race against Cambridge's Blondie.{{Cite web | url = http://www.cuwbc.org.uk/2012/03/31/henley-boat-races-2012-race-reports | title = Henley Boat Races 2012 race reports | publisher = [[Cambridge University Women's Boat Club]] | date= 31 March 2012 |accessdate = 20 May 2014}} The [[Reserve team|reserve race]], between Oxford's Isis and Cambridge's Goldie, was held thirty minutes before the main race, at 1:45pm.{{Cite web |url = http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/reserve-race-crews-finalised |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6PgJVwoKL?url=http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/reserve-race-crews-finalised |title = Reserve race crews finalised |archivedate = 19 May 2014 |accessdate = 19 May 2014 |publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited |date = 2 April 2012 |deadurl = yes |df = }} Goldie won the toss and elected to start on the Surrey station.{{Cite web |url=http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/isis-goldie-race-report |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PgJCKUeQ?url=http://theboatrace.org/men/news-article/isis-goldie-race-report |archivedate=19 May 2014 |accessdate=19 May 2014 |title=Isis Goldie race report |publisher=The Boat Race Company Ltd |date=12 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Despite rating higher and taking an early lead, Goldie was caught by Isis between [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham Football Club]] and [[Hammersmith Bridge]] at [[Barn Elms]]. Oxford's reserve boat held a half-length lead by the Mile Post, and extended their lead to over a length by [[Hammersmith Bridge]]. Isis continued to pull away and completed the race in a record time of 16 minutes 41 seconds, beating the previous best by seven seconds, five lengths ahead of Cambridge. ===Main race=== [[File:Boat Race 2012 In Hammersmith 5 (7055120451).jpg|thumb|left|The Cambridge (''foreground'') and Oxford (''background'') crews were level near Hammersmith Bridge.]] The race, sponsored by [[Xchanging]], commenced at 2:15pm, with conditions overcast and a light rain, and a light wind. The umpire for the race was John Garrett, who had rowed for the Light Blues three times in the 1980s.{{Cite web |url = http://theboatraces.org/news-article/12/umpires-announced-for-the-2012-xchanging-boat-race | title = Umpires announced for the 2012 Xchanging Boat Race| publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited | accessdate = 24 July 2014 }} Cambridge won the [[coin flipping|toss]] and chose the Surrey station, leaving Oxford with the longer outside bend from the Middlesex station.{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9192701/University-Boat-Race-2012-Cambridge-University-claim-hollow-victory-over-Oxford-University-in-ruined-race.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date =7 April 2012 | title = University Boat Race 2012: Cambridge University claim hollow victory over Oxford University in ruined race | first = Jim | last = White | accessdate = 19 May 2014 }} The crews were level at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham Football Club]] and [[Hammersmith Bridge]] but on the approach to Chiswick Pier, assistant umpire [[Matthew Pinsent]] spotted a person in the water and alerted umpire John Garrett, who stopped the race.{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9192688/University-Boat-Race-2012-Oxford-call-for-re-race-after-protester-causes-chaos-on-River-Thames.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date =7 April 2012 | title = University Boat Race 2012: Oxford call for re-race after protester causes chaos on River Thames | first = Rachel | last = Quarrell | accessdate= 19 May 2014}} Trenton Oldfield, a protestor against class [[elitism]], had swum in front of the boats as they headed into the final bend, and narrowly avoided being struck. A representative of the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] noted: "They almost took his head off".{{Cite web | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rowing/17645929 | title = Boat Race: Man charged over swimming incident | publisher = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 8 April 2012 | accessdate =18 May 2014 }} It was the first time the race had been stopped since [[The Boat Race 2001|2001]], and only the second time in the history of the event. Oldfield was pulled from the water onto the umpire's boat, handcuffed and arrested.{{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/07/class-warrior-boat-race | work = [[The Guardian]] | title = Why 'class warrior' brought the Boat Race to a standstill| first = Joshua | last = Layton | date = 7 April 2012 | accessdate = 20 May 2014}} The race was restarted some thirty minutes later, after Garrett had been satisfied that both crews were located as close as possible to where the disruption took place, in rough water caused by the flotilla following the race. Within a minute of the restart, the crews drifted together with Oxford being warned by Garrett, causing a clash of oars which resulted in Oxford's number six, Hanno Wienhausen, breaking the shaft of his blade in half. This effectively ended the race as a contest, as Cambridge rowed away from Oxford to win by four-and-a-quarter lengths. Cambridge's winning time was recorded by finish judge Ben Kent as 17 minutes 23 seconds, the consolidation of the times that the crews actually rowed.{{Cite web|url=http://theboatrace.org/statistics |title=Statistics |accessdate=16 July 2014 |publisher=The Boat Race Company Limited |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029145435/http://theboatrace.org/statistics |archivedate=29 October 2012 |df= }} ==Reaction== [[File:Oxford Crew not happy - end of Boat Race 2012.jpg|right|thumb|Oxford crew after the conclusion of the race with the number six's broken blade visible.]] ===Post-race=== Immediately after the race, Oxford's bow man, Alex Woods, collapsed and lost consciousness. After receiving treatment on the bank of the river, he was taken to [[Charing Cross Hospital]], where he made a complete recovery.{{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/07/alex-woods-oxford-boat-race | work = [[The Guardian]] | title = Oxford bow Alex Woods recovering in hospital after Boat Race collapse | first = Andy | last = Bull | date = 7 April 2012 | accessdate = 18 May 2014}} Oxford's coach Sean Bowden suggested that the loss of one of Oxford's blades had driven Woods to push himself "beyond his limits". As a result of the disruption and the concern for Woods' condition, the traditional award ceremony was cancelled. Woods later apologised to the Cambridge crew and coach for his collapse that "prevented their celebrations" while thanking them for their "sportsmanlike behaviour".{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9194472/University-Boat-Race-2012-Oxfords-collapsed-oarsman-apologises-to-Cambridge-for-spoiling-celebrations.html | date = 9 April 2012 | accessdate = 18 May 2014 | first = Rachel | last = Quarrell | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | title = University Boat Race 2012: Oxford's collapsed oarsman apologises to Cambridge for 'spoiling celebrations' }} [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge boat club]] president Nelson said "I feel bad. Finishing the race there was a lot of raw emotion and some of the celebrations seem pathetic in retrospect" while his coach Steve Trapmore commented "it's not the way anyone wants to take away the win". Oxford cox Zoe de Toledo made a request that the race be re-rowed as a result of the broken blade, but the appeal was dismissed by umpire Garrett, who said "I listened to Oxford’s complaint but I explained I did not see the clash as being the reason for the eventual result". ''[[The Observer]]'' described the race as "one of the most bizarre and dramatic in the competition's history",{{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/08/protester-halts-boat-race | title = Protester halts Boat Race by swimming into path of the Oxford crew| work = [[The Observer]] | accessdate = 16 July 2014 | first = Andy |last = Bull | date = 8 April 2012}} while ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' suggested the event had been "ruined" and described Cambridge's victory as "hollow". [[British Olympic Association]] chairman and former [[Blue (university sport)|Blue]] [[Colin Moynihan, 4th Baron Moynihan|Colin Moynihan]] claimed that the race was " effectively destroyed ... by the actions of a crazy guy who was hugely putting his life at risk".{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9192823/London-2012-Olympics-Boat-Race-protest-swimmer-Trenton-Oldfield-serves-as-a-reminder-of-Olympic-Games-threat.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | title = London 2012 Olympics: Boat Race protest swimmer Trenton Oldfield 'serves as a reminder of Olympic Games threat' | date = 8 April 2012 | accessdate = 16 July 2014}} ===Trenton Oldfield=== Oldfield, an Australian national, said he was making "a protest against inequalities in British society, government cuts, reductions in civil liberties and a culture of elitism".{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/rowing/9958656/University-Boat-Race-2013-Trenton-Oldfield-admits-if-it-was-this-cold-last-year-he-wouldnt-have-jumped-in-the-Thames.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 28 March 2013 | first = Nick | last = Pearce| title = University Boat Race 2013: Trenton Oldfield admits if it was this cold last year he wouldn't have jumped in the Thames| accessdate = 20 May 2014}} Oxford number two, William Zeng, denounced Oldfield and described him as "a mockery of a man",{{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/apr/08/boat-race-protest-reaction | work = [[The Guardian]] | title = Boat race rower blasts protester | first = Lizzy | last = Davis | first2= Andy |last2=Bull | date = 8 April 2012 | accessdate = 18 May 2014}} while Oxford boat club president Karl Hudspith tweeted "my team went through seven months of hell, this was the culmination of our careers and [Oldfield] took it from us". Educated at the [[Sydney Church of England Grammar School]], the [[University of Sydney]] and the [[London School of Economics]], and Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]], Oldfield tweeted the day after the race, "Having been deep within elite institutions I have a very good understanding of them. I protest their injustices – ask anyone that knows me".{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/australia/9193388/Trenton-Oldfield-Boat-Race-protesters-privileged-Australian-education.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 8 April 2012 | title =Trenton Oldfield: Boat Race protester's privileged Australian education | first = Jonathan | last = Pearlman | first2=Martin | last2=Evans | first3= Andrew |last3 = Hough| accessdate =20 May 2014}} On his blog, Oldfield compared his actions to those of [[Emily Davison]], the [[suffragette]] killed after stepping in front of the King's horse at [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] in 1913.{{Cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/09/world/europe/protester-disrupts-oxford-cambridge-boat-race.html?pagewanted=2&_r=0 | work = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = 20 May 2014 | title = Tradition and Boat Race Both Upended on the Thames | date = 8 April 2012 |first=John F.| last = Burns}} Despite later stating he had some sympathy for both the rowers and spectators, he said he had no regrets and that he "would have felt less of a man" had he not made the protest.{{Cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/no-regrets-says-trenton-oldfield-man-who-ruined-the-boat-race--but-dont-worry-he-wont-be-back-8554617.html | work = [[The Independent]] | title = No regrets, says Trenton Oldfield, man who ruined the boat race – but don't worry, he won’t be back | accessdate = 20 May 2014 | date = 29 March 2013 | first = Tom | last = Peck}} In October 2012, Oldfield was jailed for six months for causing a [[public nuisance]] and ordered to pay £750 [[Costs in English law|costs]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/9620280/No-good-comes-from-prejudice-judge-tells-boat-race-protester-jailed-for-six-months.html | title = 'No good comes from prejudice', judge tells boat race protester jailed for six months | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 19 October 2012 | first = Victoria | last = West| accessdate=18 May 2014}}{{Cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/boat-race-protester-trenton-oldfield-jailed-for-six-months-over-oxfordcambridge-disruption-8218456.html | work = [[The Independent]] | accessdate = 16 July 2014 | date = 19 October 2012 | title = Boat race protester Trenton Oldfield jailed for six months over Oxford-Cambridge disruption |first = Steve | last = Anderson}} In June 2013, he was refused [[Indefinite leave to remain|leave to remain]] in the United Kingdom, the [[Home Office]] claiming his presence there was not "conducive to the public good".{{Cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-23025311 | title = Boat Race protester Trenton Oldfield must leave UK | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 24 June 2013 |accessdate=18 May 2014}} Oldfield, whose wife is from India, appealed on the grounds that she would be threatened in Australia, and in December 2013, the deportation order was overturned.{{Cite web |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25303883 | title = Boat Race protester Trenton Oldfield wins deportation case | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 9 December 2013 | accessdate =18 May 2014 }} Security for the [[The Boat Race 2013|2013 race]] was increased as a result of Oldfield's actions, with [[Royal Marines]], additional stewards and the [[Metropolitan Police Marine Policing Unit]] in attendance.{{Cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-21975466 | title = Boat Race: Royal Marines to help with security | date = 29 March 2013 | accessdate = 18 May 2014 | publisher = [[BBC News]]}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|2012 University Boat Race}} *{{Official website|theboatraces.org}} {{The Boat Race}} {{Featured article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boat Race 2012}} [[Category:The Boat Race]] [[Category:2012 in English sport]] [[Category:2012 in rowing]] [[Category:April 2012 sports events]]

title: 2006 Daytona 500
text:
{{Infobox Daytona 500 | Type = NASNEX | Details ref = | Year = 2006 | Race_No = 1 | Season_No = 36 | Image = Daytona International Speedway.svg | Caption = Track map of Daytona International Speedway showing mainly the speedway. | Fulldate = {{Start date|2006|2|19}} | Location = [[Daytona International Speedway]]
[[Daytona Beach, Florida]], [[United States|U.S.]] | Course_mi = 2.5 | Course_km = 4.02336 | Distance_laps = 203 | Distance_mi = 507.5 | Distance_km = 816.742 | Scheduled_laps = 200 | Scheduled_mi = 500 | Scheduled_km = 804.672 | Weather = Temperatures reaching up to {{convert|71.6|F|C}}; wind speeds approaching {{convert|14|mph|km/h}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/FL/Daytona%20Beach/2006-02-19 |title=Weather of the ''2006 Daytona 500'' |publisher=The Old Farmers' Almanac |accessdate=2013-06-19}} | Avg = {{convert|142.734|mi/h}} | Attendance = 200,000 | Pole_Driver = [[Jeff Burton]] | Pole_Team = [[Richard Childress Racing]] | Pole_Time = 47.581 | Duel1 = [[Elliott Sadler]] | One_Team = [[Robert Yates Racing]] | Duel2 = [[Jeff Gordon]] | Two_Team = [[Hendrick Motorsports]] | Most_Driver = [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] | Most_Team = [[Dale Earnhardt, Inc.]] | Most_laps = 32 | Car = 48 | First_Driver = [[Jimmie Johnson]] | First_Team = [[Hendrick Motorsports]] | Network = [[National Broadcasting Company|NBC]] | Announcers = [[Bill Weber]], [[Benny Parsons]], and [[Wally Dallenbach Jr.]] | Ratings = 11.3/23
(19.4 million viewers) }} The '''2006 Daytona 500''', the 48th running of the [[Daytona 500|event]], was the first race in the [[2006 NASCAR Nextel Cup Series|2006 NASCAR Nextel Cup]] season. It was held on February 19, 2006 at [[Daytona International Speedway]] in [[Daytona Beach, Florida]]. [[Jimmie Johnson]] won the race in a [[green-white-checker finish]]. It was the second Daytona 500 in a row to go longer than 200 laps and {{convert|500|miles|km}}; this race, like the [[2005 Daytona 500|previous Daytona 500]], had a total distance of 203 laps and {{convert|507.5|miles|km}}. This was also the first Daytona 500 to end after dark, ending even later than the 2005 race, in which the checkered flag had waved just a few moments after sunset. Johnson's car failed pre-race inspection and as a result his crew chief, [[Chad Knaus]] was suspended for the first four races and the team was fined $200,000. As a result, [[Darian Grubb]] replaced him as crew chief. Knaus was not blocked, however, from contacting the team and by many accounts still had significant input. Johnson would go on to win his first championship that year. ==Qualifying and Gatorade Duels== {{further|2006 NASCAR Nextel Cup Series#Qualifying and Gatorade Duels}} [[Jeff Burton]] won the pole for the race with a speed of over 189 mph, and would start alongside [[Jeff Gordon]] in an all-Chevy front row. [[Elliott Sadler]] won the first Gatorade Duel (which was delayed by showers) and Gordon would win the second one, collecting his third career victory in a Daytona qualifying race. ==Race summary== The weather dawned cloudy and cold for the 48th running of the "Great American Race", as [[Jeff Burton]] led the field to the green at 2:45 p.m., which at the time was the latest scheduled start in the history of the race (the reason for this was that NBC chose it as its lead-in program to the prime-time portion of its day's coverage of the [[2006 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympic Games]] from [[Turin]]). There were several lead changes in the early part of the race, with a total of 32.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nascar/racecenter/CUP/2006/001|title=NASCAR 2006 Daytona 500 Race Results|website=CBSSports.com|accessdate=2015-11-29}} The first caution came on lap 18 when [[Martin Truex, Jr.]] hit the wall. During this caution, Burton was passed by [[Elliott Sadler]] for the lead a lap later. The race restarted on lap 20 and four laps later, [[Jeff Gordon]] took the led away from Sadler. [[Carl Edwards]], a popular "dark horse candidate" for the [[Sprint Cup Series|Nextel Cup]] championship, had his day end early, as he was involved in a five-car pileup on lap 80 that collected [[Dale Jarrett]], [[Kyle Petty]], [[Jeff Green (racing driver)|Jeff Green]], [[J.J. Yeley]], and [[Joe Nemechek]]. This was the biggest crash of the day, since the "Big One" never occurred. This would also bring out the third caution flag. Because of this, Edwards finished 43rd. [[Tony Stewart]] was a "magnet for controversy", tangling in two incidents with [[Jeff Gordon]] on lap 48 and [[Matt Kenseth]] on lap 106. The first incident, which left debris on the track, brought out the second caution and the second brought out the fifth caution. Stewart was penalized for aggressive driving after the incident with Kenseth, in which he blocked the No. 17 car into the grass, causing it to spin and hit the turn 3 wall. Kenseth took matters into his own hands and was [[Racing flag#The black flag|black-flagged]] for hitting Stewart's car in retaliation on pit road. The three drivers involved in these two incidents repaired their cars and got back into contention. [[Jimmie Johnson]] had one of the strongest cars all day. He took the lead with 10 laps to go just as the ninth caution flag came out for an crash involving Gordon, [[Kurt Busch]], [[Jamie McMurray]], and [[Sterling Marlin]]. This set up a 10-lap battle for the win. The race was extended into "overtime" when McMurray and Burton collided on lap 197, bringing out yet the 10th caution. The [[green-white-checker finish]] ended when [[Casey Mears]] and [[Ryan Newman (racing driver)|Ryan Newman]] battled for second, leaving Johnson to take the victory. The race ended under caution when [[Greg Biffle]] crashed in turn 4, just before Johnson crossed the start-finish line. The 48th running of the Daytona 500 was the first win for the #48 car on a [[restrictor plate]] track. This was also Johnson's 19th career win and his first during his streak of five consecutive NASCAR Sprint Cup Championships from [[2006 NASCAR Nextel Cup Series|2006]] to [[2010 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2010]]. One surprise of this race was [[Kirk Shelmerdine]], who finished 20th. He had barely qualified for the Daytona 500 and his independently-owned No. 27 was fielded with a car that had a borrowed engine and donated tires, as well as a team with a volunteer pit crew. ==Results== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="font-size:95%" |- ! title: 2014 NFL Draft
text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox NFL Draft | year = 2014 | image = File:2014 NFL Draft.png | imagesize = | caption = | date = May 8–10 | time = | location = [[Radio City Music Hall]]
in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|NY]] | network = [[ESPN]], [[NFL Network|NFL Network]] | first = [[Jadeveon Clowney]], DE
[[2014 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] | mr_irrelevant = [[Lonnie Ballentine]], S
Houston Texans | fewnum = 5 | fewtm1 = Indianapolis Colts | mostnum = 12 | mosttm1 = New York Jets | mosttm2 = San Francisco 49ers | overall = 256 | rounds = 7 | hofnum = }} The '''2014 NFL draft''' was the 79th annual meeting of [[National Football League]] (NFL) franchises to select newly eligible football players to the league. The draft, officially the "Player Selection Meeting",{{cite news|last=Hiro |first=Brian |title=NFL: Draft's popularity shows no signs of abating |url=http://www.nctimes.com/sports/football/professional/nfl/article_3b0aa198-379f-56e9-b122-254151e0b079.html |accessdate=January 20, 2012 |newspaper=[[North County Times]] |date=April 21, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64pyr2080?url=http://www.nctimes.com/sports/football/professional/nfl/article_3b0aa198-379f-56e9-b122-254151e0b079.html |archivedate=January 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} was held at [[Radio City Music Hall]] in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], on {{nowrap|May 8th through May 10th, 2014}}.{{cite web |last=Brinson |first=Will |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/blog/eye-on-football/22314468/2014-nfl-draft-date-set-for-may-8-10-at-radio-city-in-new-york |title=2014 NFL Draft date set for May 8–10 at Radio City in New York |publisher=[[CBS Sports]] |work=Eye on Football (blog) |date=May 28, 2013 |accessdate=May 28, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509155529/http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/22314468/2014-nfl-draft-date-set-for-may-8-10-at-radio-city-in-new-york |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.footballgeography.com/nfl-draft-sites/ |title=NFL Draft Locations |author= |date=October 2, 2014 |website=FootballGeography.com |accessdate=October 23, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905090250/http://www.footballgeography.com/nfl-draft-sites/ |archivedate=September 5, 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite news |last1=Salomone |first1=Dan |title=NFL Draft headed to Chicago in 2015 |url=http://www.giants.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/NFL-Draft-headed-to-Chicago-in-2015/3ac322b1-3b4c-4a16-aba7-6e08d31b1756 |accessdate=June 3, 2015 |publisher=[[New York Giants]] |work=Giants.com |date=October 2, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930065327/http://www.giants.com/news-and-blogs/article-1/NFL-Draft-headed-to-Chicago-in-2015/3ac322b1-3b4c-4a16-aba7-6e08d31b1756 |archivedate=September 30, 2015 |deadurl=no}} One of the most anticipated drafts in recent years kicked off on May 8, 2014 at 8 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]].{{cite web |title=2014 NFL Draft notes |url=http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/draft-notes-2014.pdf |publisher=[[National Football League]] |accessdate=May 9, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506192929/http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/draft-notes-2014.pdf |archivedate=May 6, 2014 |format=PDF |deadurl=no}} The draft was moved from its traditional time frame in late April due to a scheduling conflict at [[Radio City Music Hall]].{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9301153/roger-goodell-confirms-nfl-draft-moving-2014 |title=Roger Goodell: Draft shifts to May |publisher=ESPN |date=May 22, 2013 |accessdate=May 28, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102131009/http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9301153/roger-goodell-confirms-nfl-draft-moving-2014 |archivedate=November 2, 2013 |deadurl=no}} There was early discussion and rumors leading up to the draft on the future of staying at the current location in New York City, where it has been held since {{nfly|1965}}. Given the increased interest the draft has garnered over the past decade,{{cite news |last=Gagnon |first=Brad |title=How the NFL Draft became the biggest non-sporting sports event |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/apr/22/nfl-draft-2013-biggest-non-sport |accessdate=May 13, 2014 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 22, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228195732/http://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/apr/22/nfl-draft-2013-biggest-non-sport |archivedate=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=no}} there was belief that the event may have outgrown [[Radio City Music Hall]], which has been the venue for the past nine drafts. The possibility of extending the draft to four days was also being discussed throughout the months leading up to the draft. The NFL decided in that summer that the [[2015 NFL Draft]] will take place at the Auditorium Theatre in Chicago, Illinois. The [[2014 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] opened the draft by selecting defensive end [[Jadeveon Clowney]] from the [[2013 South Carolina Gamecocks football team|University of South Carolina]]. The last time a defensive player was taken with the first overall selection was in [[2006 NFL Draft|2006]], when the Texans selected [[Mario Williams]].{{cite web |title=2014 NFL Draft round 1 notes |url=http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/draft-notes-2014-radio-city.pdf |publisher=[[National Football League]] |accessdate=May 14, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514151849/http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/draft-notes-2014-radio-city.pdf |archivedate=May 14, 2014 |format=PDF |deadurl=no}} The Texans also closed the draft with the selection of safety [[Lonnie Ballentine]] of the [[2013 Memphis Tigers football team|University of Memphis]] as [[Mr. Irrelevant]], which is the title given to the final player selected.{{cite news|last=Corbett |first=Jim |title='Mr. Irrelevant' Lonnie Ballentine could prove title wrong |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/draft/2014/05/10/mr-irrelevant-nfl-draft-2014-lonnie-ballentine-houston-texans/8949701/ |accessdate=May 14, 2014 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=May 11, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PZcRExDT?url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/draft/2014/05/10/mr-irrelevant-nfl-draft-2014-lonnie-ballentine-houston-texans/8949701/ |archivedate=May 14, 2014 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The 2014 NFL draft made history when the [[2014 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]] selected [[Michael Sam]] in the seventh round. Sam, who became the first openly gay player to ever be drafted in the NFL, was selected 249th out of 256 picks in the '''2014 NFL Draft'''. After this, Sam's jersey was the second best selling rookie jersey on the NFL's website. {{cite web |last=Silver |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Silver (sportswriter) |title=St. Louis Rams draft Michael Sam, make NFL history |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000349452/article/st-louis-rams-draft-michael-sam-make-nfl-history |publisher=[[NFL.com]] |accessdate=May 12, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512142901/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000349452/article/st-louis-rams-draft-michael-sam-make-nfl-history |archivedate=May 12, 2014 |deadurl=no}} Sam [[coming out|came out]] publicly in the months leading up to the draft.{{cite web |last=Connelly |first=Chris |title=Mizzou's Michael Sam says he's gay |url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/10429030/michael-sam-missouri-tigers-says-gay |work=[[Outside the Lines]] (blog) |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=May 7, 2014 |authorlink=Chris Connelly (journalist) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426235128/http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/10429030/michael-sam-missouri-tigers-says-gay |archivedate=April 26, 2014 |date=February 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} A few notable players drafted in 2014 were [[Jimmy Garoppolo|Jimmy Garappolo]], [[Johnny Manziel]], [[Derek Carr]], [[Blake Bortles]], [[Khalil Mack]], [[Odell Beckham Jr.]], [[Aaron Donald]], [[Anthony Barr (American football)|Anthony Barr]], [[Allen Robinson]], [[Jadeveon Clowney]], [[Mike Evans (wide receiver)|Mike Evans]], [[Devonta Freeman]], and [[Sammy Watkins (American football)|Sammy Watkins]]. {{TOC left}} ==Early entrants== {{Main article|List of 2014 NFL draft early entrants}} A record 98 underclassmen announced their intention to forgo their remaining [[National Collegiate Athletic Association#Eligibility|NCAA eligibility]] and declare themselves available to be selected in the draft.{{cite web|title=98 Players Granted Special Eligibility for 2014 NFL Draft |url=http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/01-19-14-special-eligibility.pdf |accessdate=March 11, 2014 |publisher=[[National Football League]] |format=PDF |date=January 19, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NzqZA8MM?url=http://nfllabor.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/01-19-14-special-eligibility.pdf |archivedate=March 11, 2014 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} When including four players who received degrees but still had eligibility remaining, the number swells to 102.{{cite web |last=Heitner |first=Darren |title=No Need To Bash The Record Ninety-Eight Underclassmen Declaring For NFL Draft |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2014/01/19/no-need-to-bash-the-record-ninety-eight-underclassmen-declaring-for-nfl-draft/ |publisher=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=May 9, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415194936/http://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2014/01/19/no-need-to-bash-the-record-ninety-eight-underclassmen-declaring-for-nfl-draft/ |archivedate=April 15, 2014 |date=January 19, 2014 |deadurl=no}} Fourteen underclassmen—plus [[Teddy Bridgewater]] who graduated with eligibility remaining—were selected in the draft's first round, including the first four and six of the first ten players selected.{{cite web|last=Gribble|first=Andrew|title=Tracking the underclassmen: Close to 40 percent don't hear their name called at 2014 NFL Draft|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2014/05/tracking_the_underclassmen_nfl.html|work=Alabama Crimson Tide Sports (blog)|publisher=[[The Birmingham News]]|accessdate=May 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140511023018/http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2014/05/tracking_the_underclassmen_nfl.html|archivedate=May 11, 2014|date=May 10, 2014}} ==Overview== The following is the breakdown of the 256 players selected by [[American football positions|position]]: {| | *34 [[Linebacker]]s *33 [[Wide receiver]]s *33 [[Cornerback]]s *22 [[Defensive end]]s *20 [[Offensive tackle]]s | *20 [[Defensive tackle]]s *20 [[Running back]]s *20 [[Safety (American football position)|Safeties]] *15 [[Guard (American football)|Offensive guards]] *14 [[Quarterback]]s | *10 [[Center (American football)|Centers]] *10 [[Tight end]]s *2 [[Fullback (American football)|Fullbacks]] *2 [[Kicker (American football)|Kickers]] *1 [[Punter (American football)|Punter]] |} ==Determination of draft order== {{details|National Football League draft#Rules for determining draft order}} The draft order is based generally on each team's [[2013 NFL season#Final standings|record from the previous season]], with teams which qualified for the [[2012-13 NFL Playoffs|postseason]] selecting after those which failed to make the playoffs.{{cite web|title=Complete order of first round of 2011 NFL Draft determined |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d81d6b708/article/complete-order-of-first-round-of-2011-nfl-draft-determined |publisher=[[National Football League|NFL.com]] |accessdate=May 8, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/630aYvpPt?url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d81d6b708/article/complete-order-of-first-round-of-2011-nfl-draft-determined |archivedate=November 7, 2011 |date=January 2, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The [[2014 Houston Texans season|Houston Texans]] with a 2–14 record in [[2013 Houston Texans season|2013]] held the first selection of each round. The [[2013 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] and [[2013 Baltimore Ravens season|Baltimore Ravens]] finished {{nfly|2013}} with identical 8–8 records and strength of schedule ratings, hence a coin flip was used to determine the selection order — the Cowboys won the flip and thus selected ahead of the Ravens.{{cite web |last=Reynolds |first=Jeff |title=2014 NFL Draft: Cowboys win coin flip vs. Ravens, pick 16th |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/draft/nfl-draft-scout/24448335/nfl-draft-cowboys-win-coin-flip-pick-16th |work=NFLDraftScout.com |publisher=[[CBS Sports]] |accessdate=May 12, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224013157/http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/draft/nfl-draft-scout/24448335/nfl-draft-cowboys-win-coin-flip-pick-16th |archivedate=February 24, 2014 |date=February 19, 2014 |deadurl=no}} ==Player selections== {| border=0 cellspacing="0" cellpadding="8" |- |{{NFLDraft-TOC |numberofrounds=7|center=yes}} {|style="margin: 0.75em 0 0 0.5em;" |- | style="background-color:#d9e9f9; border:1px solid #aaaaaa; width:2em;" align=center| * | = [[NFL draft#Compensatory picks|compensatory]] selection || |- | style="background:#faecc8; border:1px solid #aaa; width:2em; text-align:center;"| † | = [[Pro Bowl]]erPlayers are identified as a Pro Bowler if they were selected for the Pro Bowl at any time in their career. |} | cellspacing="2"| {{AmFootball position key modern}} |} {{NFLDraft-header | noteswidth=250pt}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=1 | firstpickinround=yes | team=Houston Texans| first=Jadeveon | last=Clowney | position=DE | collegeyear=2013| college=South Carolina| collegeteam= South Carolina Gamecocks | collegelink=South Carolina | probowl= yes |note=|cfb page exists=yes }} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=2 | team=St. Louis Rams| first=Greg| last=Robinson|dab= Greg Robinson (offensive tackle)| position=OT | collegeyear=2013 | college= Auburn| collegeteam= Auburn Tigers| collegelink= Auburn| probowl= |note=from [[2014 Washington Redskins season|Washington]] {{#tag:ref|{{Anchor|RedskinsRamsRGIII}}'''No. 2: Washington → St. Louis (PD).''' Washington traded this selection along with its first and second round selections in [[2012 NFL Draft|2012]] ([[2012 NFL Draft#Pick 6|6th]] & [[2012 NFL Draft#Pick 39|39th]]) and its first round selection in [[2013 NFL Draft|2013]] ([[2013 NFL Draft#Pick 22|22nd]]) to St. Louis in exchange for St. Louis' 2012 first round selection ([[2012 NFL Draft#Pick 2|2nd]]) which Washington used to select [[Robert Griffin III]].{{cite news| last=Glazer |first=Jay |authorlink=Jay Glazer |title=NFL 'Skins deal for No. 2 pick, target RG3? |url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/washington-redskins-trade-for-st-louis-rams-nfl-draft-pick-robert-griffin-iii-washington-bound-030912 |accessdate=April 30, 2012 |publisher=[[FOX Sports]] |date=March 22, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507235443/http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/washington-redskins-trade-for-st-louis-rams-nfl-draft-pick-robert-griffin-iii-washington-bound-030912 |archivedate=May 7, 2014 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Michael David |title=Greg Robinson is the final piece of the Robert Griffin III trade |url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/05/12/greg-robinson-is-the-final-piece-of-the-robert-griffin-iii-trade/ |work=[[Profootballtalk.com|Pro Football Talk]] |publisher=[[NBC Sports]] |accessdate=May 13, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513164910/http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/05/12/greg-robinson-is-the-final-piece-of-the-robert-griffin-iii-trade/ |archivedate=May 13, 2014 |date=May 12, 2014 |deadurl=no}}|group="R1 -"}} |cfb page exists= yes}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=3 | team=Jacksonville Jaguars| first= Blake| last= Bortles|dab= | position=QB | collegeyear= 2013| college= University of Central Florida| collegeteam= UCF Knights| collegelink= UCF| probowl=no|note= |cfb page exists=yes }} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=4 | team=Buffalo Bills| first= Sammy| last= Watkins |dab= Sammy Watkins (American football) | position=WR | collegeyear= 2013| college= Clemson| collegeteam= Clemson Tigers| collegelink= Clemson| probowl=no |note=from [[2014 Cleveland Browns season|Cleveland]] {{#tag:ref|{{Anchor|BrownsBillsWatkins}}'''No. 4: Cleveland → Buffalo (D).''' Cleveland traded this selection to Buffalo in exchange for Buffalo's 2014 first round selection ([[#Pick 9|9th]]), and their first and fourth round selections in [[2015 NFL Draft|2015]] ([[2015 NFL Draft#Pick 19|19th]] & [[2015 NFL Draft#Pick 115|115th]]).{{cite web |last=Patra |first=Kevin |title=Bills grab Sammy Watkins after trading up to No. 4 |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000348048/article/bills-trade-up-for-no-4-pick-from-browns-draft-watkins |publisher=[[NFL.com]] |work=Around the League (blog) |date=May 8, 2014 |accessdate=May 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509201904/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000348048/article/bills-trade-up-for-no-4-pick-from-browns-draft-watkins |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=no}}|group="R1 -"}} |cfb page exists= yes}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=5 | team=Oakland Raiders| first= Khalil| last=Mack|dab= | position= LB| collegeyear= 2013| college=University at Buffalo | collegeteam= Buffalo Bulls| collegelink= Buffalo| probowl=yes |note=|cfb page exists= yes}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=6 | team=Atlanta Falcons| first=Jake| last=Matthews|dab= | position= OT| collegeyear= 2013| college= Texas A&M| collegeteam= Texas A&M Aggies| collegelink= Texas A&M| probowl= |note= |cfb page exists= yes}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=7 | team=Tampa Bay Buccaneers| first=Mike| last=Evans|dab= Mike Evans (wide receiver)| position= WR| collegeyear= 2013| college= Texas A&M| collegeteam= Texas A&M Aggies| collegelink= Texas A&M| probowl=yes |note= |cfb page exists= yes}} {{NFLDraft-row| draftyear=2014 |round=1 | picknum=8 | team=Cleveland Browns| first=Justin | last=Gilbert|dab= | position= CB| collegeyear= 2013| college= Oklahoma State| collegeteam= Oklahoma State Cowboys| collegelink= Oklahoma State| probowl= |note=from [[2014 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota]] {{#tag:ref|{{Anchor|VikingsBrownsGilbertBarr}}'''No. 8: Minnesota → Cleveland (D).''' Philadelphia traded running back [[Bryce Brown]] along with Philadelphia's seventh round selection ([[#Pick 237|237th]]) to Buffalo in exchange for this selection and a conditional future mid-round draft pick. ==Trades== In the explanations below, '''(D)''' denotes trades that took place during the 2014 draft, while '''(PD)''' indicates trades completed pre-draft. ;Round one ;Round two ;Round three ;Round four ;Round five ;Round six ;Round seven ==Supplemental draft== The [[supplemental draft]] was held on July 10, 2014. For each player selected in the supplemental draft, the team forfeits its pick in that round in the draft of the following season. 4 players were eligible, but for the second straight year no players were selected.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Huguenin |title=No players selected in 2014 NFL Supplemental Draft |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000364264/article/no-one-is-selected-in-2014-nfl-supplemental-draft |work=NFL.com |publisher=NFL Enterprises LLC. |date=July 10, 2014 |accessdate=July 10, 2014 }} ==Summary== The [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) led all college athletic conferences in terms of first round selections with eleven, including the first two picks of the draft.{{cite news |last=Wilner |first=Barry |title=NFL draft 2014: Texans take South Carolina's Clowney first overall; Manziel goes to Cleveland |url=http://sports.nationalpost.com/2014/05/09/nfl-draft-2014-texans-take-south-carolinas-clowney-first-overall-manziel-goes-to-cleveland/ |accessdate=May 9, 2014 |newspaper=[[National Post]] |date=May 9, 2014 |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] }} For the first time since the league's second draft in [[1937 NFL Draft|1937]], no player from the [[Texas Longhorns football|University of Texas]] was selected.{{cite news |last=Trotter |first=Jake |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/draft2014/story/_/id/10914219/2014-nfl-draft-texas-longhorns-zero-players-drafted |title=NFL teams ignore Longhorns |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=May 11, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512082710/http://espn.go.com/nfl/draft2014/story/_/id/10914219/2014-nfl-draft-texas-longhorns-zero-players-drafted |archivedate=May 12, 2014 |deadurl=no}} For the second year in succession — and only the second time since [[1967 NFL Draft|1967]] — no running back was selected in the first round.{{cite web |last=Chappell |first=Bill |title=NFL Draft's First Round: Manziel Slides, No Running Backs Taken |url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/05/09/310968162/nfl-drafts-first-round-manziel-slides-no-running-backs-taken |work=The Two-Way (blog) |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=May 16, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516050213/http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2014/05/09/310968162/nfl-drafts-first-round-manziel-slides-no-running-backs-taken |archivedate=May 16, 2014 |date=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=no}} The first player taken at the position was [[Bishop Sankey]] who was selected in the second round with the 54th pick overall. This is the latest point in the history of the draft for the first running back to be selected.{{cite web |last=Davis |first=Charles |title=What 2014 NFL Draft told us about state of college football |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000350491/article/what-2014-nfl-draft-told-us-about-state-of-college-football |date=May 15, 2014| accessdate=May 15, 2014 |publisher=[[NFL.com]] |work=CFB 24/7:Path to the Draft (blog) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516142810/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000350491/article/what-2014-nfl-draft-told-us-about-state-of-college-football |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|'''3''' |} ==U.S. television coverage== The draft was broadcast [[Live television|live]] by the [[NFL Network]] and [[ESPN]]. This marks the 35th year of draft coverage on ESPN while the NFL Network has covered the draft since its inception ten years ago.{{cite web |last=Deitsch |first=Richard |title=Inside the wall-to-wall coverage of the 2014 NFL draft |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/more/news/20140504/richard-deitsch-media-circus-nfl-draft/ |work=Media Circus (blog) |publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]] |accessdate=May 14, 2014 |authorlink=Richard Deitsch |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505112932/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/more/news/20140504/richard-deitsch-media-circus-nfl-draft/ |archivedate=May 5, 2014 |date=May 4, 2014 |deadurl=no}} The two networks' combined first-round coverage drew a record 32 million viewers according to [[Nielsen ratings]] which was a 28 percent increase over the previous year. In total 45.7 million viewers watched some part of the three-day event, topping the previous record of 45.4 millions set in [[2010 NFL Draft|2010]].{{cite web |title=Record 45.7 Million Viewers for 2014 NFL Draft |url=http://nflcommunications.com/2014/05/12/record-45-7-million-viewers-for-2014-nfl-draft/ |publisher=[[National Football League]] |accessdate=May 14, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514175903/http://nflcommunications.com/2014/05/12/record-45-7-million-viewers-for-2014-nfl-draft/ |archivedate=May 14, 2014 |date=May 12, 2014 |deadurl=no}} ==In popular culture== * The events of the 2014 film ''[[Draft Day]]'', take place during the fictionalized 2014 NFL Draft. ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|group=N}} ;General references {{Reflist}} ;Trade references {{Reflist|group=source}} ==External links== *[http://www.nfl.com/draft/2014 Official Site] *[http://espn.go.com/nfl/draft2014/ 2014 NFL Draft at ESPN] {{NFL drafts}} {{2014 NFL season by team}} [[Category:National Football League Draft]] [[Category:2014 in sports in New York City|NFL Draft]] [[Category:2014 National Football League season|Draft]] [[Category:American football in New York (state)]] [[Category:Radio City Music Hall]] [[Category:Sports in Manhattan]]

| score = 6–4, 6–3
| before_name = Wimbledon Championships – Girls' Singles
| after_name  = Wimbledon Championships – Girls' Singles
| type = grand slam
}}
{{main|1975 Wimbledon Championships}}
[[Natasha Chmyreva]] defeated [[Regina Maršíková]] in the final, 6–4, 6–3 to win the Girls' Singles tennis title at the 1975 Wimbledon Championships.<ref name="girlss">{{cite web|title=Girls' Singles Finals 1947-2017|url=http://www.wimbledon.com/en_GB/roll_of_honour/girlssingles.html|website=wimbledon.com|publisher=[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Championships]]|accessdate=13 August 2017}}</ref>

title: 2010 Speedway World Cup Final
text:
{{Infobox SWC Event
 |NAME      =2010 FIM Speedway World Cup – Final

}}

The '''2010 FIM PGE [[Polska Grupa Energetyczna]] Speedway World Cup Final''' was the fourth and the final race of the [[2010 Speedway World Cup]] season. The event took place on August 1, 2010, at the [[Vojens Speedway Center|Speedway Center]] in [[Vojens]], [[Denmark]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Supplementary Regulations | publisher = fim-live.com | date =  | url = http://www.fim-live.com/fileadmin/alfresco/Manifestations/SR_SWC_Final_new.pdf | accessdate = 2010-06-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Drużynowy Puchar Świata | publisher = pzm.pl | date = 2010-07-30 | url = http://www.pzm.pl/zuzel/,c,1329,DRUZYNOWY_PUCHAR_SWIATA_2010__7 | accessdate = 2010-07-30 }}</ref>

The race was initially scheduled for July 31; it was cancelled after Heat 4, however, when the track was deemed unsuitable by the [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] Jury due to adverse weather conditions. The race was re-staged on the next day at 3pm.<ref>{{cite web | title = Deszcz wygrał z DPŚ - zawody przełożone na niedzielę! | publisher = SportoweFakty.pl | date = 2010-07-31 | language = Polish | url = http://www.sportowefakty.pl/zuzel/2010/07/31/deszcz-wygral-z-dps-zawody-przelozone-na-niedziele/ | accessdate = 2010-08-01 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100803005511/http://www.sportowefakty.pl/zuzel/2010/07/31/deszcz-wygral-z-dps-zawody-przelozone-na-niedziele/| archivedate= 3 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
